The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection A, inserted "or lesser" following "greater"; in subsection B, substituted "specified or fixed" for "fixed or prescribed"; in subsection C, added "or unless otherwise expressly provided in this chapter" at the end; in subdivision D 1, substituted "the director's" for "his"; rewrote subdivision D 2, which read: "The director votes against, or abstains from, the action taken"; added subdivision D 3; in subsection E, substituted "may be provided in an agreement authorized by" for "provided in"; and made stylistic changes.

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 3A M.J. Banks and Banking, § 93.

§ 13.1-689. Committees.

  1. Unless the articles of incorporation or bylaws provide otherwise, a board of directors may establish one or more committees of the board of directors to perform functions of the board of directors and appoint two or more directors of the board of directors to serve on each committee. While non-board members may also be appointed to a committee, they may not vote on any matter for which the committee is performing a function of the board of directors. Each committee member serves at the pleasure of the board of directors.
  2. Unless the articles of incorporation or bylaws provide otherwise, the establishment of a committee and appointment of members to it shall be approved by the greater number of (i) a majority of all the directors in office when the action is taken or (ii) the number of directors required by the articles of incorporation or bylaws to take action under § 13.1-688.
  3. Sections 13.1-684 through 13.1-688, which govern meetings, action without meetings, notice and waiver of notice, and quorum and voting requirements of the board of directors, apply to committees and their members as well.
  4. To the extent specified by the board of directors or in the articles of incorporation or bylaws, each committee may exercise the authority of the board of directors under § 13.1-673, except that a committee may not:
    1. Approve or propose to shareholders action that this chapter requires to be approved by shareholders;
    2. Fill vacancies on the board of directors or, subject to subsection E, on any committee;
    3. Amend the articles of incorporation pursuant to § 13.1-706;
    4. Adopt, amend, or repeal the bylaws;
    5. Approve a plan of merger not requiring shareholder approval;
    6. Authorize or approve a distribution, except according to a formula or method, or within limits, prescribed by the board of directors; or
    7. Authorize or approve the issuance or sale or contract for sale of shares, or determine the designation and rights, preferences, and limitations of a class or series of shares, except that the board of directors may (i) authorize a committee to do so subject to such limits, if any, as may be prescribed by the board of directors, and (ii) authorize a senior executive officer of the corporation to do so subject to such limits, if any, as may be prescribed by the board of directors or by subsection C of § 13.1-646.
  5. The board of directors may appoint one or more directors as alternate members of any committee to replace any absent or disqualified member during the member's absence or disqualification. Unless the articles of incorporation or the bylaws or the resolutions of the board of directors establishing the committee provide otherwise, in the event of the absence or disqualification of a member of a committee and there are no alternate members appointed by the board of directors, the member or members of the committee present at any meeting and not disqualified from voting may by unanimous action appoint another director to act in place of the absent or disqualified member during that member's absence or disqualification.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-40; 1956, c. 428; 1975, c. 500; 1980, c. 341; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2010, c. 782; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted "shall" for "may" in the second sentence of subsection A; substituted "chapter" for "Act" in subdivision D 1; in subdivision D 7, deleted "relative" preceding "rights," and substituted "to do so subject to such limits if any, as may be prescribed by the board of directors" for "to do so within limits specifically prescribed by the board of directors"; and added subsection F.

The 2010 amendments. - The 2010 amendment by c. 782, in subdivision D 7, added the clause (i) designator; deleted "or a senior executive officer of the corporation" following "authorize a committee," and added clause (ii).

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote subsection A, which read: "Unless the articles of incorporation or bylaws provide otherwise, a board of directors may create one or more committees and appoint members of the board of directors to serve on them. Each committee shall have two or more members, who serve at the pleasure of the board of directors"; in subsection B, substituted "Unless the articles of incorporation or bylaws provide otherwise, the establishment" for "The creation"; in subdivision D 1, substituted "propose" for "recommend"; rewrote subdivision D 2, which read: "Fill vacancies on the board on any of its committees"; in subdivision D 6, deleted "general" preceding "formula," and inserted "or within limits" following "method"; deleted former subsection E, which read: "The creation of, delegation of authority to, or action by a committee does not alone constitute compliance by a director with the standards of conduct described in § 13.1-690"; redesignated former subsection F as E; and rewrote subsection E, which read: "The board of directors may appoint one or more directors as alternate members of any committee to replace any absent or disqualified member during the member's absence or disqualification. Unless the articles of incorporation or the bylaws or the resolution creating the committee provide otherwise, in the event of the absence or disqualification of a member of a committee, the member or members present at any meeting and not disqualified from voting, unanimously may appoint another director to act in place of the absent or disqualified member"; and made stylistic changes.

CASE NOTES

Burden of proving committee decision in corporation's best interest. - A corporation has the burden of proving the independence and good faith of a special litigation committee and that it performed a reasonable investigation to provide reasonable bases for its conclusion that a shareholder derivative suit would not be in the best interests of the corporation or its shareholders. Abella v. Universal Leaf Tobacco Co., 546 F. Supp. 795 (E.D. Va. 1982) (decided under prior law).

Court review of committee decision to dismiss derivative suit. - The trial court should apply its own independent business judgment to decide whether to dismiss a shareholder derivative suit which has been dismissed by a corporation's special litigation committee, taking into account many factors - ethical, commercial, promotional, public relations, employee relations, fiscal as well as legal. Abella v. Universal Leaf Tobacco Co., 546 F. Supp. 795 (E.D. Va. 1982) (decided under prior law).

§ 13.1-690. General standards of conduct for director.

  1. A director shall discharge his duties as a director, including his duties as a member of a committee, in accordance with his good faith business judgment of the best interests of the corporation.
  2. Unless a director has knowledge or information concerning the matter in question that makes reliance unwarranted, the director is entitled to rely on information, opinions, reports, or statements, including financial statements and other financial data, if prepared or presented by:
    1. One or more officers or employees of the corporation whom the director believes, in good faith, to be reliable and competent in the matters presented;
    2. Legal counsel, public accountants, or other persons as to matters the director believes, in good faith, are within the person's professional or expert competence; or
    3. A committee of the board of directors of which he is not a member if the director believes, in good faith, that the committee merits confidence.
  3. A director is not liable for any action taken as a director, or any failure to take any action, if he performed the duties of his office in compliance with this section.
  4. A person alleging a violation of this section has the burden of proving the violation.

(Code 1950, §§ 13-206, 13-207, 13.1-44; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 2019, c. 734.)

Cross references. - As to trustee standard of conduct, trustee liability and restrictions on liability limitations in governing instruments under the Virginia Business Trust Act, see § 13.1-1229.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection B, substituted "a director" for "he"; and made stylistic changes.

Law review. - For note, "The Defensive and Offensive Use of 'Poison Pills' Within the Business Judgment Rule," see 24 U. Rich. L. Rev. 127 (1989).

For 1991 survey of business and corporate law, see 25 U. Rich. L. Rev. 627 (1991).

For an essay, "The Shaping Force of Corporate Law In the New Economic Order," see 31 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1473 (1997).

For an article, "Misunderstanding Director Duties: The Strange Case of Virginia," see 56 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 1127 (1999).

For article reviewing changes in Virginia corporate and business law from June 2001 through May 2002, see 37 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1 (2002).

For comment, "Private Ordering in the Old Dominion: A Solution to Frivolous Litigation or the Elimination of a Fundamental Shareholder Right?" see 53 U. Rich. L. Rev. 297 (2018).

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 3A M.J. Banks and Banking, § 93.

CASE NOTES

Commerce Clause not violated. - The Affiliated Transactions Act ( § 13.1-725 et seq.), the Control Share Acquisitions Act ( § 13.1-728.1 et seq.), the poison pill statute ( § 13.1-646), and the business judgment statute (this section), do not violate the Commerce Clause. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

Flow of interstate commerce not eliminated. - The Virginia takeover statutes do not completely eliminate the flow of interstate commerce in hostile takeover attempts of Virginia corporations. More to the point, they do not remove competition for corporate control or hoard a local resource. Any potential acquiror that makes an adequate offer may gain control of a Virginia corporation; the Virginia statutes just make it more expensive to do so. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

Virginia need not define its corporations as other states do; it must only provide residents and nonresidents with equal access to them. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

No Williams Act preemption. - The Williams Act ( §§ 15 U.S.C. 78m(d)-(e), 78n(d)-(f)), which regulates disclosure to shareholders and procedures required in tender offers, does not preempt the Affiliated Transactions Act ( § 13.1-725 et seq.), the Control Share Acquisitions Act ( § 13.1-728.1 et seq.), the poison pill statute ( § 13.1-646), and the business judgment statute (this section), either separately or together. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

Statutes not part of integrated scheme. - The Affiliated Transactions Act ( § 13.1-725 et seq.), the Control Share Acquisitions Act ( § 13.1-728.1 et seq.), the poison pill statute ( § 13.1-646), and the business judgment statute (this section) are not parts of an integrated program. They were enacted separately at separate times for separate purposes and with separate applications. Their only apparent link is that they all affect company's hostile takeover attempts. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

Effect on tender offers. - Through § 13.1-646, this section, § 13.1-725 et seq., and § 13.1-728.1 et seq., Virginia has given certain tools to shareholders and management, acting in the best interests of the corporation, to ensure that tender offers succeed only if they are consistent with the long-term interests of the corporation. Shareholders of Virginia corporations need not fear the coercive pressures of two-tiered tender offers or the prospect of corporate raiders seeking to extract greenmail by threatening to immediately dismantle and sell a corporation's assets. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

Investors not impacted detrimentally by statutory scheme. - The Virginia statutory scheme makes tender offers for Virginia corporations more difficult than they would be absent the statutes. But although the statutes seem to give power to management with the same hand that takes it away from offerors, they do not do so to the detriment of investors. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

This section refers to the positive duties required of directors by the statute law. Anderson v. Bundy, 161 Va. 1, 171 S.E. 501 (1933) (decided under prior law). See also Marshall v. Fredericksburg Lumber Co., 162 Va. 136, 173 S.E. 553 (1934) (decided under prior law).

Good faith business judgment. - Decision making process engaged in by directors demonstrated that their actions were taken in compliance with their good faith business judgment of the best interests of the corporation. As a result, counterclaims alleging breaches of fiduciary duty must fail. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 869 F. Supp. 419 (W.D. Va. 1994).

Summary judgment was granted in favor of defendants because plaintiffs failed to show that defendants breached their fiduciary duty as directors of the company because at the time defendants agreed to purchase plaintiffs' company, defendants' company was solvent and as such defendants' decision did not involve fraud, bad faith or unconscionable conduct; therefore, defendants were entitled to Virginia's business judgment rule, § 13.1-690. Poth v. Russey, 281 F. Supp. 2d 814, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15813 (E.D. Va. 2003).

Protection only to acts or omissions as director. - The protection of this section applies only to acts "taken as a director, or any failure to take any action," and is confined to the exercise of business judgment on behalf of the corporation; when the acts in question do not meet these criteria, this section does not apply. Simmons v. Miller, 261 Va. 561, 544 S.E.2d 666, 2001 Va. LEXIS 48 (2001).

Personal liability of director found. - Unless he complies with the applicable standards of conduct described in this section, a director who votes for or assents to a distribution made in violation of Chapter 9 of Title 13.1 of the Code is personally liable to the corporation and its creditors for the amount of the distribution that exceeds what could have been distributed without violating Chapter 9. Commonwealth Transp. Comm'r v. Matyiko, 481 S.E.2d 468 (1997).

No protection for organization of competitor. - Clearly, the organization of a competitor was not a corporate act of the corporation of which the defendant was a director and, in taking this action, the director was not exercising business judgment on behalf of the corporation; although implicating a common-law duty of loyalty, this act did not fall within the scope of this section and the defendant was not entitled to protection under the statutory business judgment rule. Simmons v. Miller, 261 Va. 561, 544 S.E.2d 666, 2001 Va. LEXIS 48 (2001).

"Safe harbor" exception to director liability. - Because section 13.1-692 conditions its imposition of personal liability upon a director's failure to comply with the standards of conduct described in this section, a "safe harbor" is provided to a director who does comply with those standards. Commonwealth Transp. Comm'r v. Matyiko, 481 S.E.2d 468 (1997).

This section does not abrogate the common law duties of a director but does set the standard by which a director is to discharge those duties; if a director acts in accordance with that standard, the statute provides a safe harbor that shields a director from liability for any action taken as a director and for failure to take action. Willard v. Moneta Bldg. Supply, Inc., 258 Va. 140, 515 S.E.2d 277 (1999).

This section establishes the standard by which to evaluate a director's discharge of duties and, if a director acts in accordance with that standard, subsection C provides a "safe harbor" that shields him from liability for any action taken as a director, or any failure to take any action. Dellastatious v. Williams, 242 F.3d 191, 2001 U.S. App. LEXIS 2615 (4th Cir. 2001).

This section is a radical departure from the former common law and statutory business judgment standards. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 155 F.R.D. 142 (W.D. Va. 1994), aff'd, 65 F.3d 1172 (4th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1117, 116 S. Ct. 921, 133 L. Ed. 2d 850 (1996).

Precedential authority of C-T . - The court in C.T. of Va., Inc. v. Barrett , 124 Bankr. 694 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1990) was correct to the extent it adopted a business judgment rule similar to that in Unocal Corp. v. Mesa Petroleum Co. , 493 A.2d 946 (Del. 1985), but because its operative facts predated the enactment of this section, C-T is of little precedential authority on the discoverability of the director decision-making process. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 155 F.R.D. 142 (W.D. Va. 1994), aff'd, 65 F.3d 1172 (4th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1117, 116 S. Ct. 921, 133 L. Ed. 2d 850 (1996).

This section is process-oriented in that it permits inquiry into the process by which the decision was made rather than the substance of the information processed by the director in making the business decision. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 155 F.R.D. 142 (W.D. Va. 1994), aff'd, 65 F.3d 1172 (4th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1117, 116 S. Ct. 921, 133 L. Ed. 2d 850 (1996).

A director's discharge of duties is not measured by what a reasonable person would do in similar circumstances or by the rationality of the ultimate decision; instead, a director must act in accordance with his good faith business judgment of what is in the best interests of the corporation. Willard v. Moneta Bldg. Supply, Inc., 258 Va. 140, 515 S.E.2d 277 (1999).

Duty to obtain highest price for shareholders. - It is well-established in corporate law that when the sale of a firm is inevitable, the directors' duty is to obtain the highest price for shareholders. C-T of Va., Inc. v. Barrett, 124 Bankr. 694 (W.D. Va. 1990), aff'd, 958 F.2d 606 (4th Cir. 1992).

And duty cannot extend to interests of current or future unsecured creditors. - Board of director's announcement that it had authorized the sale of the company to management in a leveraged buyout signalled that the company was for sale. At that point, the board was not merely considering a possibility of merger with a particular corporation; it had already determined that the best way to serve shareholder interests was to place the firm on the market. Accordingly, the directors' duties were limited to those specified by Revlon, Inc. v. MacAndrews & Forbes Holding, Inc. , 506 A.2d 173 (Del. 1986): to gain the highest possible price for its shareholders; the duty cannot extend to the interests of current or future unsecured creditors of the company. C-T of Va., Inc. v. Barrett, 124 Bankr. 689 (W.D. Va. 1990).

Directors may consider factors other than price. - The directors of a corporation are entitled to consider the quantity and quality of offers to purchase the corporation's assets and are not required to accept an offer merely because it maximizes the purchase price; such a rule would mean that only one offer, among many, was in the best interests of the corporation and would erode the deference afforded a director's discharge of duties under the statute. Willard v. Moneta Bldg. Supply, Inc., 258 Va. 140, 515 S.E.2d 277 (1999).

"Good faith" under this section presents the question of whether a process was engaged that would produce a defensible business decision. The procedural soundness of a business decision may be assessed by examining the qualifications of the persons with whom the director consulted; the general topics, not the substance, of the information sought or imparted; and, even whether the advice was followed. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 155 F.R.D. 142 (W.D. Va. 1994), aff'd, 65 F.3d 1172 (4th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1117, 116 S. Ct. 921, 133 L. Ed. 2d 850 (1996).

Where shareholders allege that directors have insufficiently supervised the corporation's affairs, directors can avoid liability by showing that they attempted in good faith to ensure that an adequate corporate information gathering and reporting system was in place. Dellastatious v. Williams, 242 F.3d 191, 2001 U.S. App. LEXIS 2615 (4th Cir. 2001).

Director's reliance on the advice of experts. - A director can rely on information and opinions from, inter alia, legal counsel, accountants and other experts unless the director has knowledge that such reliance is unwarranted; a director may use an informed decision-making process in discharging the duties of the office as long as the director does so in good faith and, when a director resorts to such a process, the ultimate decision must still reflect the director's good faith business judgment of the best interests of the corporation in order to receive the benefit of the safe harbor afforded in the code. Willard v. Moneta Bldg. Supply, Inc., 258 Va. 140, 515 S.E.2d 277 (1999).

As long as directors have no knowledge that makes reliance unwarranted, they may rely on financial statements prepared by corporate officers, legal counsel, or public accountants. Dellastatious v. Williams, 242 F.3d 191, 2001 U.S. App. LEXIS 2615 (4th Cir. 2001).

A party challenging the actions of the board of directors has the burden of proving that the challenged action was not undertaken in accordance with the directors' good faith business judgment of the best interests of the corporation; however, when a conflict of interest as defined in § 13.1-691 exists, the burden shifts to the directors to show that their actions complied with the requirements of that section. Izadpanah v. Boeing Joint Venture, 243 Va. 81, 412 S.E.2d 708 (1992).

Direct action by member against manager for breach of fiduciary duty not allowed. - See Remora Invs., L.L.C. v. Orr, 277 Va. 316, 673 S.E.2d 845, 2009 Va. LEXIS 26 (2009).

Discoverable procedural indicia. - Where acquiring corporation objected to orders of the magistrate judge to the extent they prevented the party from inquiring, in discovery, into the substance of professional advice given to target corporation in the face of takeover attempt, the court held that the statute permits inquiry into the procedural indicia of whether the directors resorted in good faith to an informed decision-making process. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 857 F. Supp. 492 (W.D. Va. 1994), aff'd, 65 F.3d 1172 (4th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1117, 116 S. Ct. 921, 133 L. Ed. 2d 850 (1996).

Valid record date found. - Where board of directors of corporation subject to takeover attempt fixed the record date as the date on which acquiring corporation submitted its control share acquisition statement, and where the board undertook an informed decision-making process with regard to the selection of a record date, the record date was valid pursuant to Virginia law. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 857 F. Supp. 496 (W.D. Va. 1994).

No fiduciary duty found. - Regarding a former member's claims against a limited liability company (LLC), equitable subordination was not warranted, because the LLC did not demonstrate a sufficient factual basis for the court to find inequitable conduct or harm since, inter alia, the court could not conclude that the former member breached the duty to refrain from self-dealing since the court could not find that such duty existed, and the LLC did not prove the violation of the fiduciary duty of care. In re Virginia Broadband, LLC, 521 Bankr. 539, 2014 Bankr. LEXIS 4638 (Bankr. W.D. Va. Nov. 5, 2014), aff'd, 538 Bankr. 253, 2015 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 122638 (W.D. Va. 2015).

Shareholders as "directors." - The trial court erred in dismissing plaintiff's claim against corporation shareholders for unlawful distribution of corporate assets because, although the defendant shareholders were not duly elected directors of the dealership, they had assumed and exercised the duties of directors without benefit of formal election; consequently, they were "directors" for purposes of this section and §§ 13.1-653 and 13.1-692. Curley v. Dahlgren Chrysler-Plymouth, Dodge, Inc., 245 Va. 429, 429 S.E.2d 221 (1993).

A Virginia corporation is an entity (1) in which shareholders holding over one-fifth of the shares have no voting rights absent consent of the directors or the disinterested shareholders; (2) that cannot be merged into another entity for three years without consent of its directors; (3) that can issue discriminatory rights to the detriment of some of its shareholders, provided that such discrimination is in the best interests of the corporation; and (4) whose directors must conduct themselves based upon their good faith business judgment of the best interests of the corporation, and who may satisfy this standard by relying in good faith on competent advice received pursuant to an informational process undertaken in good faith. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 861 F. Supp. 1277 (W.D. Va. 1994).

Sufficiency of pleading. - Where a liquidating trustee of a corporate bankruptcy debtor alleged that, while the debtor was insolvent, the former directors of the debtor engaged in or acquiesced in transactions in which they were self-interested, which were not fair to the debtor and preferred shareholders over creditors, the trustee properly alleged a claim for breach of fiduciary duty against the directors. Schnelling v. Crawford (In re James River Coal Co.), 360 Bankr. 139, 2007 Bankr. LEXIS 159 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 2007).

Allegations sufficient to withstand motion to dismiss. - Claims a liquidating trustee asserted in an adversary proceeding he filed against the directors and shareholders of a privately-held company that offered clinical laboratory services to physicians before it was placed into Chapter 11 bankruptcy, which alleged, inter alia, that the shareholders breached the covenant of good faith and fair dealing implied in a shareholder agreement when they canceled the agreement and converted the company to a C corporation to avoid personal liability for taxes, and aided and abetted the directors in breaching their common law fiduciary duties and their fiduciary duties under § 13.1-690, were sufficient to survive the directors and shareholders' motion to dismiss. Arrowsmith v. Warnick (In re Health Diagnostic Lab., Inc.),, 2018 Bankr. LEXIS 2953 (Bankr. E.D. Va. Sept. 27, 2018).

Applied in Owens v. Owens, 41 Va. App. 844, 589 S.E.2d 488, 2003 Va. App. LEXIS 639 (2003).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Applicability. - Demurrer was sustained as to limited liability company members' claim against individuals of breach of fiduciary duty because (1) a member could not bring such a claim against a manager or another member, (2) the Virginia Stock Corporation Act did not apply, and (3) the source of duty rule barred a claim of breach of a limited liability company agreement. Johnson v. Bella Gravida, LLC, 105 Va. Cir. 350, 2020 Va. Cir. LEXIS 103 (Fairfax County July 20, 2020).

"Safe harbor" exception to director liability. - When shareholders of a closely held corporation sought judicial dissolution of the corporation, the business judgment rule did not insulate the corporation's board of directors from liability because the shareholders showed that the board of directors merely "rubberstamped" the decisions of a director. Colgate v. Disthene Group, Inc., 85 Va. Cir. 286, 2012 Va. Cir. LEXIS 67 (Buckingham County Aug. 30, 2012).

Business judgment rule not properly reached by demurrer. - Whether defendants' actions or lack of action that were the subject of a breach of fiduciary duty claim were entitled to the protection of the business judgment rule under § 13.1-690 was an issue of proof for trial that was not properly reached by demurrer. Colgate v. Disthene Group, Inc., 86 Va. Cir. 218, 2013 Va. Cir. LEXIS 9 (Buckingham County Feb. 4, 2013).

§ 13.1-690.1. Director of open-end management investment company deemed disinterested.

A director of a corporation that is an open-end management investment company, as defined by the federal Investment Company Act of 1940, who with respect to the corporation is not an interested person, as defined by the federal Investment Company Act of 1940, shall be deemed to be disinterested when making any determination or taking any action as a director of the corporation.

(2006, c. 330; 2019, c. 734.)

Editor's note. - For the Investment Company Act of 1940, referred to above, see 15 U.S.C.S. § 80a-1 et seq.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 inserted "federal" preceding "Investment" twice; deleted "independent and" preceding "disinterested"; and added "of the corporation" at the end.

Law review. - For 2007 annual survey article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 42 U. Rich. L. Rev. 273 (2007).

§ 13.1-691. Director conflict of interests.

  1. A conflict of interests transaction is a transaction with the corporation in which a director of the corporation has an interest that precludes the director from being a disinterested director. A conflict of interests transaction is not voidable by the corporation solely because of the director's interest in the transaction if any one of the following is true:
    1. The material facts of the transaction and the director's interest were disclosed or known to the board of directors or a committee of the board of directors and the board of directors or committee authorized, approved, or ratified the transaction;
    2. The material facts of the transaction and the director's interest were disclosed to the shareholders entitled to vote and they authorized, approved, or ratified the transaction; or
    3. The transaction was fair to the corporation.
  2. For purposes of subdivision A 1, a conflict of interests transaction is authorized, approved, or ratified if it receives the affirmative vote of a majority of the disinterested directors on the board of directors, or on the committee. A transaction shall not be authorized, approved, or ratified under this section by a single director. If a majority of the disinterested directors vote to authorize, approve or ratify the transaction, a quorum is present for the purpose of taking action under this section. The presence of, or a vote cast by, a director who is not disinterested does not affect the validity of any action taken under subdivision A 1 if the transaction is otherwise authorized, approved or ratified as provided in that subsection.
  3. For purposes of subdivision A 2, a conflict of interests transaction is authorized, approved, or ratified if it receives the vote of a majority of the shares entitled to be counted under this subsection. Shares owned by or voted under the control of a director who is not disinterested may not be counted in a vote of shareholders to determine whether to authorize, approve, or ratify a conflict of interests transaction under subdivision A 2. The vote of those shares, however, shall be counted in determining whether the transaction is approved under other sections of this chapter. A majority of the shares, whether or not present, that are entitled to be counted in a vote on the transaction under this subsection constitutes a quorum for the purpose of taking action under this section.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-39.1; 1975, c. 500; 1980, c. 341; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765.)

Cross references. - As to trustee standard of conduct, trustee liability and restrictions on liability limitations in governing instruments under the Virginia Business Trust Act, see § 13.1-1229.

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted "has an interest that precludes the director from being a disinterested director" for "has a direct or indirect personal interest" in the first sentence in subsection A; deleted former subsection B, relating to directors with an indirect personal interest in transactions; and rewrote former subsections C and D and redesignated them as present subsections B and C.

CASE NOTES

The scope of Virginia's director conflict law was narrowed from that previously provided under former § 13.1-39.1 when the General Assembly enacted this section. Under this section, transactions in which a director has an interest are not void, only voidable, a marked change from the previous statutory provision which rendered them void. Furthermore, a transaction in which a director has a direct or indirect interest is not voidable if certain statutory provisions apply. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 155 F.R.D. 142 (W.D. Va. 1994), aff'd, 65 F.3d 1172 (4th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1117, 116 S. Ct. 921, 133 L. Ed. 2d 850 (1996).

Transaction with corporation required for conflict of interests. - This section defines a conflict of interests transaction as a transaction with the corporation, and there is no such transaction when the plaintiff alleges that the director caused the corporation to waive its right of first refusal with respect to the purchase of the plaintiff's stock and that the director thereafter purchased the stock as a private individual. Byelick v. Vivadelli, 79 F. Supp. 2d 610 (E.D. Va. 1999).

Director conflict claim necessitates no knowledge of substance of advice given. - Irrespective of who carries the initial burden of proof and when during the course of litigation it might shift, the bottom line is that none of the elements of a director conflict claim or defense involves the need for knowing the substance of advice given the director before or during a transaction. WLR Foods, Inc. v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 155 F.R.D. 142 (W.D. Va. 1994), aff'd, 65 F.3d 1172 (4th Cir. 1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1117, 116 S. Ct. 921, 133 L. Ed. 2d 850 (1996).

Dealings of director with corporation closely scrutinized. - The relationship between a director and his corporation is one of trust, and the court must subject the dealings of a director with his corporation to close and rigorous scrutiny. Adams Labs., Inc. v. Garrett, 3 Bankr. 495 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1980) (decided under prior law).

Fairness of transaction. - No inflexible rule can be established by which to test the fairness of a transaction but, generally, a director must act in good faith and the transaction must, as a whole, be open, fair and honest at the time it was consummated; a transaction in which a director has a conflict of interest should bear the earmarks of an arm's length bargain in order to be deemed fair to the corporation. Willard v. Moneta Bldg. Supply, Inc., 258 Va. 140, 515 S.E.2d 277 (1999).

If the court determines that a transaction was fair to the corporation, it need not address whether the directors in fact had a conflict of interests. Willard v. Moneta Bldg. Supply, Inc., 258 Va. 140, 515 S.E.2d 277 (1999).

Director may not acquire personal advantage or profit in breach of duty to corporation. - A director of a private corporation cannot directly or indirectly, in any transaction in which he is under a duty to guard the interest of the corporation, acquire any personal advantage or make any profit for himself, and if he does so, he may be compelled to account therefor to the corporation. Tanner's Transf. & Storage of Va., Inc. v. Florance, 22 Bankr. 24 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1982) (decided under prior law).

When a conflict of interest exists, burden of proof shifts to directors. - A party challenging the actions of the board of directors has the burden of proving that the challenged action was not undertaken in accordance with the directors' good faith business judgment of the best interests of the corporation; however, when a conflict of interest as defined in this section exists, the burden shifts to the directors to show that their actions complied with the requirements of that section. Izadpanah v. Boeing Joint Venture, 243 Va. 81, 412 S.E.2d 708 (1992).

Shareholder in close corporation may challenge transaction. - Considered in perspective of the fiduciary duties in a closely held corporation, the legislative history of this section and supreme court dicta, a shareholder can challenge an interested director transaction in a close corporation under this section. Byelick v. Vivadelli, 79 F. Supp. 2d 610 (E.D. Va. 1999).

Professional advice irrelevant. - In judging the fairness to a corporation of an interested director transaction, the substance of professional advice given to and relied upon by a defendant is immaterial because such advice is not probative of the nature of the conflict, nor of whether the transaction was fair to the corporation; fairness must be established irrespective of advice sought or given. Byelick v. Vivadelli, 79 F. Supp. 2d 610 (E.D. Va. 1999).

No duty existed for former member. - Regarding a former member's claims against a limited liability company (LLC), equitable subordination was not warranted, because the LLC did not demonstrate a sufficient factual basis for the court to find inequitable conduct or harm since, inter alia, the court could not conclude that the former member breached the duty to refrain from self-dealing since the court could not find that such duty existed. In re Virginia Broadband, LLC, 521 Bankr. 539, 2014 Bankr. LEXIS 4638 (Bankr. W.D. Va. Nov. 5, 2014), aff'd, 538 Bankr. 253, 2015 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 122638 (W.D. Va. 2015).

Shareholder's claim. - Shareholder's direct conflict of interest claim against directors was dismissed because the claim could be brought only through a shareholder derivative suit. DCG&T ex rel. Battaglia v. Knight, 68 F. Supp. 3d 579, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 174996 (E.D. Va. Dec. 18, 2014), appeal dismissed, 648 Fed. Appx. 342, 2016 U.S. App. LEXIS 8816 (4th Cir. Va. 2016).

Sufficiency of derivative claim. - Shareholder's derivative conflict of interest claim against directors survived dismissal because the shareholder met its initial burden of asserting a conflict of interest among the directors and whether defendants could assert a full disclosure defense involved a question of fact that could not be resolved on a motion to dismiss. DCG&T ex rel. Battaglia v. Knight, 68 F. Supp. 3d 579, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 174996 (E.D. Va. Dec. 18, 2014), appeal dismissed, 648 Fed. Appx. 342, 2016 U.S. App. LEXIS 8816 (4th Cir. Va. 2016).

Limitation of remedies. - Where shareholder sought to undo a merger, the limitation of remedies to appraisal rights did not apply if the merger was an interested transaction and the shareholder had plausibly alleged that the merger was an impermissible conflict of interest transaction. DCG&T ex rel. Battaglia v. Knight, 68 F. Supp. 3d 579, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 174996 (E.D. Va. Dec. 18, 2014), appeal dismissed, 648 Fed. Appx. 342, 2016 U.S. App. LEXIS 8816 (4th Cir. Va. 2016).

Applied in Virginia Bankshares, Inc. v. Sandberg, 501 U.S. 1083, 111 S. Ct. 2749, 115 L. Ed. 2d 929 (1991).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Business judgment doctrine. - Although the decisions to establish defendant's compensation as CEO of a small corporation, initially grant defendant an interest-free loan, and not call the loan prior to a decedent shareholder's death were not protected by the business judgment doctrine because they were conflict-of-interest transactions, those decisions were protected and/or were cured as allowed by statute. However, the decision not to call the loan due once demanded was an improper discharge of defendant's duties as a director that was not cured by an applicable statutory provision. O'Brien v. Midgett, 96 Va. Cir. 177, 2017 Va. Cir. LEXIS 119 (Virginia Beach July 26, 2017).

Waiver of conflict. - Because shareholders would be considered shareholders entitled to vote on the corporation's consent to dual representation, they could not waive a conflict if one later arose in the case; the court is in no way precluded from relying on the statute governing conflict of interest transactions to interpret the meaning of "shareholders" as used in Va. Sup. Ct. R. pt. 6, § II, R. 1.13(e). Foley v. Mid-Atlantic Leasing Corp., 102 Va. Cir. 1, 2019 Va. Cir. LEXIS 87 (Chesapeake Mar. 20, 2019).

§ 13.1-691.1. Business opportunities.

  1. A director's taking advantage, directly or indirectly, of a business opportunity may not be the subject of equitable relief, or give rise to an award of damages or other sanctions against the director, in a proceeding by or in the right of the corporation on the ground that such opportunity should have first been offered to the corporation, if before becoming legally obligated respecting the opportunity the director brings it to the attention of the corporation and:
    1. Directors' action disclaiming the corporation's interest in the opportunity is taken in compliance with the procedures set forth in subdivision A 1 of § 13.1-691, as if the decision being made concerned a director's conflict of interests transaction; or
    2. Shareholders' action disclaiming the corporation's interest in the opportunity is taken in compliance with the procedures set forth in subdivision A 2 of § 13.1-691, as if the decision being made concerned a director's conflict of interests transaction.
  2. In any proceeding seeking equitable relief or other remedies, based upon an alleged improper taking advantage of a business opportunity by a director, the fact that the director did not employ one of the procedures described in subsection A before taking advantage of the opportunity shall not create an inference that the opportunity should have been first presented to the corporation or alter the burden of proof otherwise applicable to establish that the director breached a duty to the corporation in the circumstances.

(2005, c. 765.)

CASE NOTES

Exculpatory clause. - Exculpatory clause in articles of incorporation did not defeat complaint at motion to dismiss stage because factual allegations plausibly stated willful misconduct, including that the directors sought to enrich themselves and disregard the best interests of the corporation. DCG&T ex rel. Battaglia v. Knight, 68 F. Supp. 3d 579, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 174996 (E.D. Va. Dec. 18, 2014), appeal dismissed, 648 Fed. Appx. 342, 2016 U.S. App. LEXIS 8816 (4th Cir. Va. 2016).

§ 13.1-692. Liability for unlawful distributions.

  1. A director who votes for or assents to a distribution in excess of what may be authorized and made pursuant to this chapter or the articles of incorporation is personally liable to the corporation and its creditors for the amount of the distribution that exceeds what could have been distributed without violating this chapter or the articles of incorporation if the party asserting liability establishes that when taking the action the director did not comply with § 13.1-690.
  2. A director held liable for an unlawful distribution under subsection A is entitled to:
    1. Contribution from every other director who could be held liable under subsection A for the unlawful distribution; and
    2. Recoupment from the shareholders who received the unlawful distribution in proportion to the amounts of such unlawful distribution received by them respectively.
  3. No suit shall be brought against any director for any liability imposed by subsection A except within two years after the right of action shall accrue.
  4. Contribution or recoupment under subsection B is barred unless it is commenced within one year after the liability of the claimant has been finally adjudicated under subsection A.

(Code 1950, §§ 13-206, 13-207, 13.1-44; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765, in subsection A, deleted the beginning which read: "Unless he complies with the applicable standards of conduct described in § 13.1 690" and added "if the party asserting liability establishes that when taking the action the director did not comply with § 13.1-690" to the end; in subsection B, deleted "of this section" preceding "is entitled to" and deleted "contribution" following "is entitled to"; rewrote subdivision B 1; added "Recoupment" to the beginning of subdivision B 2; substituted "subsection A" for "this section" in subsection C; and added subsection D.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection A, substituted "in excess of what may be authorized and made pursuant to" for "made in violation of."

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, § 110.

CASE NOTES

Corporation's board of directors liability for a distribution must depend entirely on their premerger actions. Where the uncontradicted evidence demonstrated that the directors intended to transfer ownership of the corporation as a going enterprise and were not seeking to hide a distribution of the firm's assets to the shareholders, no unlawful distribution occurred. Further, to the extent the events associated with the buyout might have been considered a distribution, the defendants were no longer directors at the time it was approved by the board, so they could not be held liable. C-T of Va., Inc. v. Barrett, 124 Bankr. 694 (W.D. Va. 1990), aff'd, 958 F.2d 606 (4th Cir. 1992).

Personal liability of director found. - Unless he complies with the applicable standards of conduct described in § 13.1-690, a director who votes for or assents to a distribution made in violation of Chapter 9 of Title 13.1 of the Code is personally liable to the corporation and its creditors for the amount of the distribution that exceeds what could have been distributed without violating Chapter 9. Commonwealth Transp. Comm'r v. Matyiko, 481 S.E.2d 468 (1997).

Because this section conditions its imposition of personal liability upon a director's failure to comply with the standards of conduct described in § 13.1-690, a "safe harbor" is provided to a director who does comply with those standards. Commonwealth Transp. Comm'r v. Matyiko, 481 S.E.2d 468 (1997).

Inapplicable to third party payments. - This section is aimed by its terms at actions taken by a corporation to enrich unjustly its own shareholders at the expense of creditors and to the detriment of the continuing viability of the company. It does not cover third-party payments to acquire the stock of a corporation or the encumbering of assets after a change in corporate ownership and it is not intended to obstruct an arm's-length acquisition of an enterprise by new owners who have their own plans for commercial success. C-T of Va., Inc. v. Barrett, 958 F.2d 606 (4th Cir. 1992).

The two-year limitation is not applicable to all acts of directors as such. Anderson v. Bundy, 161 Va. 1, 171 S.E. 501 (1933) (decided under prior law).

Shareholders as "directors." - The trial court erred in dismissing plaintiff's claim against corporation shareholders for unlawful distribution of corporate assets because, although the defendant shareholders were not duly elected directors of the dealership, they had assumed and exercised the duties of directors without benefit of formal election; consequently, they were "directors" for purposes of this section and §§ 13.1-653 and 13.1-690. Curley v. Dahlgren Chrysler-Plymouth, Dodge, Inc., 245 Va. 429, 429 S.E.2d 221 (1993).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Director's and majority shareholder's personal liability established. - Where a majority shareholder directed that only a small portion of the proceeds from the sale of corporate property be wired to pay other debts into the corporate account, while instructing the buyer to wire the remaining amounts (more than 90 percent of the total paid at the sale) into his and a director's personal bank accounts, this evidence not only showed that the shareholder was aware of the collection proceedings against the corporation, but that the acts of procuring a significant personal and pecuniary benefit from the sale of the corporate property were illegal to warrant personal liability to the corporation's debtors and an insurer, who had paid the corporate debt and became subrogated to a federal judgment creditor. Lawyers Title Ins. Corp. v. P.R.T. Enters., 65 Va. Cir. 271, 2004 Va. Cir. LEXIS 286 (Norfolk 2004).

§ 13.1-692.1. Limitation on liability of officers and directors; exception.

  1. In any proceeding brought by or in the right of a corporation or brought by or on behalf of shareholders of the corporation, the damages assessed against an officer or director arising out of a single transaction, occurrence or course of conduct shall not exceed the lesser of:
    1. The monetary amount, including the elimination of liability, specified in the articles of incorporation or, if approved by the shareholders, in the bylaws as a limitation on or elimination of the liability of the officer or director; or
    2. The greater of (i) $100,000 or (ii) the amount of cash compensation received by the officer or director from the corporation during the 12 months immediately preceding the act or omission for which liability was imposed.
  2. The liability of an officer or director shall not be limited as provided in this section if the officer or director engaged in willful misconduct or a knowing violation of the criminal law or of any federal or state securities law, including, without limitation, any claim of unlawful insider trading or manipulation of the market for any security.
  3. No limitation or elimination of liability adopted pursuant to this section may be affected by any amendment of the articles of incorporation or bylaws with respect to any action or omission occurring before such amendment.

(1987, cc. 59, 257; 1988, c. 561; 2019, c. 734; 2020, c. 1226.)

Editor's note. - Acts 2020, c. 1226, cl. 3 provides: "That the provisions of the first and second enactments of this act shall become effective July 1, 2021."

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 deleted former subsection C, which read: "No limitation on or elimination of liability adopted pursuant to this section may be affected by any amendment of the articles of incorporation or bylaws with respect to any act or omission occurring before such amendment"; and made a stylistic change.

The 2020 amendments. - The 2020 amendment by c. 1226, effective July 1, 2021, added subsection C.

Law review. - For 1991 survey of business and corporate law, see 25 U. Rich. L. Rev. 627 (1991).

For an article, "Misunderstanding Director Duties: The Strange Case of Virginia," see 56 Wash. & Lee L. Rev. 1127 (1999).

For annual survey article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 46 U. Rich. L. Rev. 41 (2011).

For survey article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 8 U. Rich. L. Rev. 39 (2013).

For comment, "Private Ordering in the Old Dominion: A Solution to Frivolous Litigation or the Elimination of a Fundamental Shareholder Right?" see 53 U. Rich. L. Rev. 297 (2018).

CASE NOTES

Willful conduct. - Claims for directors' and officers' breach of fiduciary duty could be assigned to plaintiff trustee under 11 U.S.C.S. § 1123(a)(5). The limitation on damages under Virginia law did not apply in the case of willful misconduct under 11 U.S.C.S. § 523(a)(6) and subsection B of § 13.1-692.1. Affirmative defenses under the exculpatory provisions of Md. Code Ann., Corps. & Ass'ns. § 2-405.2 and Md. Code Ann., Cts. & Jud. Proc. § 5-418 were also limited. Matson v. Alpert (In re LandAmerica Fin. Group, Inc.), 470 Bankr. 759, 2012 Bankr. LEXIS 819 (2012).

§ 13.1-693. Required officers.

  1. Except as provided in an agreement authorized by § 13.1-671.1, a corporation shall have such officers with such titles and duties as shall be described in the bylaws or in a resolution of the board of directors that is in accordance with the bylaws and as may be necessary to enable it to execute documents that comply with subsection F of § 13.1-604.
  2. Officers shall be elected by the board of directors, except that an officer may appoint one or more officers or assistant officers if authorized by the bylaws or the board of directors.
  3. The secretary of the corporation shall have the responsibility for preparing the minutes of the directors' and shareholders' meetings and for maintaining and authenticating the records of the corporation required to be kept under subsection E of § 13.1-770.
  4. The same individual may simultaneously hold more than one office in a corporation.
  5. Election or appointment of an officer does not of itself create any contract rights in the officer or the corporation.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-45; 1956, c. 428; 1972, c. 606; 1975, c. 500; 1982, c. 372; 1985, c. 522; 1994, c. 189; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765 added "Except as provided in an agreement authorized by § 13.1-671.1" to the beginning of subsection A; and substituted "The board of directors may elect individuals to fill one or more offices of the corporation. An officer" for "A duly appointed officer" in subsection B.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote the section.

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, §§ 55, 149.

CASE NOTES

A secretary of a corporation is a mere servant. His position is that he is to do what he is told and no person can assume that he has any authority to represent anything at all. Taylor v. Sutherlin-Meade Tobacco Co., 107 Va. 787, 60 S.E. 132 (1908) (decided under prior law).

§ 13.1-694. Duties of officers.

  1. Each officer has the authority and shall perform the duties set forth in the bylaws or, to the extent consistent with the bylaws, the duties prescribed by the board of directors or by direction of an officer authorized by the board of directors to prescribe the duties of other officers.
  2. In discharging his duties, an officer who does not have knowledge that makes reliance unwarranted is entitled to rely on:
    1. The performance of properly delegated responsibilities by one or more employees of the corporation whom the officer believes in good faith to be reliable and competent in performing the responsibilities delegated; or
    2. Information, opinions, reports or statements, including financial statements and other financial data, prepared or presented by one or more employees of the corporation whom the officer believes in good faith to be reliable and competent in the matters presented or by legal counsel, public accountants, or other persons retained by the corporation as to matters involving skills or expertise the officer believes in good faith are matters (i) within the particular person's professional or expert competence or (ii) as to which the particular person merits confidence.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-45; 1956, c. 428; 1972, c. 606; 1975, c. 500; 1982, c. 372; 1985, c. 522; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 inserted the subsection A designation and added subsection B.

CASE NOTES

Duty of fidelity. - A corporate officer has the same duties of fidelity in dealing with the corporation that arise in dealings between a trustee and a beneficiary of the trust. Giannotti v. Hamway, 239 Va. 14, 387 S.E.2d 725 (1990).

Sale of asset by close corporation absent express resolution. - Where all the stockholders and directors of a close corporation agree or acquiesce in a real estate transaction involving only a minor holding, one not even used in the corporation's business, the corporation is bound by the transaction, notwithstanding the absence of a formal resolution authorizing the sale. Lake Motel, Inc. v. Lowery, 224 Va. 553, 299 S.E.2d 496 (1983) (decided under prior law).

§ 13.1-695. Resignation and removal of officers.

  1. An officer may resign at any time by delivering a written notice to the board of directors, its chairman, the appointing officer, if any, or the corporation's secretary. A resignation is effective as provided in subdivision A 9 of § 13.1-610 unless the notice provides for a delayed effectiveness. If effectiveness of a resignation is stated to be delayed and the board of directors or the appointing officer, if any, accepts the delay, the board of directors or the appointing officer, if any, may fill the pending vacancy before the delayed effectiveness but the new officer may not take office until the vacancy occurs.
  2. An officer may be removed at any time with or without cause by (i) the board of directors; (ii) the appointing officer, if any, unless the bylaws or the board of directors provides otherwise; or (iii) any other officer, if authorized by the bylaws or the board of directors. An officer's removal does not affect such officer's contract rights, if any, with the corporation. An officer's resignation does not affect the corporation's contract rights, if any, with the officer.
  3. Any person who has resigned as an officer of a corporation, or whose name is of record in the office of the clerk of the Commission as an officer of a corporation, may file a statement to that effect with the Commission.
  4. Upon the resignation or removal of an officer, the corporation may file an amended annual report with the Commission indicating the resignation or removal of the officer and the successor in office, if any.
  5. As used in this section "appointing officer" means the officer, including any successor to that officer, who, in accordance with subsection B of § 13.1-693, appointed the officer who is resigning or being removed.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-46; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 1990, c. 282; 1991, cc. 124, 146; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734; 2020, c. 1226.)

Editor's note. - Acts 2020, c. 1226, cl. 3 provides: "That the provisions of the first and second enactments of this act shall become effective July 1, 2021."

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765, in subsection A, substituted "time" for "date" three times, substituted "time" for "date and" once, and deleted "accepts the future effective date, it" preceding "may fill the pending vacancy" in the second sentence; and added "if any" to the end of subsection D.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote the section.

The 2020 amendments. - The 2020 amendment by c. 1226, effective July 1, 2021, substituted "subdivision A 9" for "subdivision 9" in the second sentence of subsection A.

CASE NOTES

Effect on workers' compensation claims. - Dismissal of worker's compensation claim was affirmed, where the employer presented evidence in the form of corporate minutes that it had fewer than three employees at the time of the claimant's injury. Estate of Pelfrey v. Sorah, No. 0647-03-3, 2003 Va. App. LEXIS 387 (Ct. of Appeals July 8, 2003).

Article 10.
Indemnification.

§ 13.1-696. Definitions.

As used in this article:

"Corporation" includes any corporation and any domestic or foreign predecessor entity of a corporation in a merger or other transaction in which the predecessor's existence ceased upon consummation of the transaction.

"Director" or "officer" means an individual who is or was a director or officer, respectively, of a corporation or who, while a director or officer of the corporation, is or was serving at the corporation's request as a director, officer, manager, partner, trustee, employee, or agent of another entity or employee benefit plan. A director or officer is considered to be serving an employee benefit plan at the corporation's request if the individual's duties to the corporation also impose duties on, or otherwise involve services by, the individual to the plan or to participants in or beneficiaries of the plan. "Director" or "officer" includes, unless the context requires otherwise, the estate or personal representative of a director or officer.

"Liability" means the obligation to pay a judgment, settlement, penalty, fine, including any excise tax assessed with respect to an employee benefit plan, or expenses incurred with respect to a proceeding.

"Official capacity" means (i) when used with respect to a director, the office of director in a corporation and (ii) when used with respect to an officer, as contemplated in § 13.1-702, the office in a corporation held by the officer. "Official capacity" does not include service for any other entity or employee benefit plan.

"Party" means an individual who was, is, or is threatened to be made a defendant or respondent in a proceeding.

"Proceeding" means any threatened, pending, or completed action, suit, or proceeding, whether civil, criminal, administrative, arbitrative, or investigative and whether formal or informal.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-3.1; 1968, c. 570; 1975, c. 500; 1979, c. 99; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2009, c. 587; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765, in the first paragraph, inserted "corporation and any domestic" preceding "or foreign predecessor" and inserted "domestic" preceding "corporation"; in the first sentence of the second paragraph, inserted "or officer, respectively" following "or was a director," deleted "or an individual" following "of a corporation," inserted "manager" preceding "partner, trustee," inserted "limited liability company" preceding "partnership, joint venture," substituted "or other entity" for "or other enterprise," and inserted "or officer" throughout the paragraph; in the first sentence of the fifth paragraph, substituted "officer" for "individual other than a director," and deleted "or the employment or agency relationship undertaken by the employee or agent on behalf of the corporation" at the end, and in the second sentence, substituted "entity" for "enterprise"; and substituted "means" for "includes" in the sixth paragraph.

The 2009 amendments. - The 2009 amendment by c. 587, effective retroactive to July 1, 2005, substituted "corporation or who" for "corporation who" in the first sentence of the paragraph defining "Director" or "officer."

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in the definition for "Corporation," deleted "domestic" preceding "corporation" twice; in the definition for "Director," substituted "entity or employee benefit plan" for "foreign or domestic corporation, limited liability company, partnership, joint venture, trust, employee benefit plan, or other entity," substituted "the individual's" for "his" and made a related change; deleted the definition for "Expenses," which read: "'Expenses' includes counsel fees"; in the definition for "Liability," deleted "reasonable" preceding "expenses"; in the definition for "Official capacity," substituted "entity or employee benefit plan" for "foreign or domestic corporation or any partnership, joint venture, trust, employee benefit plan, or other entity"; and in the definition for "Party," deleted "named" preceding "defendant"; and made stylistic changes.

Law review. - For article, "The New Virginia Stock Corporation Act: A Primer," see 20 U. Rich. L. Rev. 67 (1985).

For an article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 32 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1067 (1998).

For annual survey article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 44 U. Rich. L. Rev. 307 (2009).

§ 13.1-697. Authority to indemnify.

  1. Except as provided in subsection D, a corporation may indemnify an individual who is a party to a proceeding because the individual is or was a director against liability incurred in the proceeding if:
    1. The director:
      1. Conducted himself in good faith; and
      2. Believed:
        1. In the case of conduct in his official capacity with the corporation, that his conduct was in its best interests; and
        2. In all other cases, that his conduct was at least not opposed to its best interests; and
      3. In the case of any criminal proceeding, he had no reasonable cause to believe his conduct was unlawful; or
    2. The director engaged in conduct for which broader indemnification has been made permissible or obligatory as authorized by subsection C of § 13.1-704.
  2. A director's conduct with respect to an employee benefit plan for a purpose he believed to be in the interests of the participants in and beneficiaries of the plan is conduct that satisfies the requirement of subdivision A 1 b (2).
  3. The termination of a proceeding by judgment, order, settlement, or conviction, or upon a plea of nolo contendere or its equivalent, is not, of itself, determinative that the director did not meet the relevant standard of conduct described in this section.
  4. Unless ordered by a court under subsection C of § 13.1-700.1 or broader indemnification has been made permissible or obligatory as authorized by subsection C of § 13.1-704, a corporation may not indemnify a director under this section:
    1. In connection with a proceeding by or in the right of the corporation except for expenses incurred in connection with the proceeding if it is determined that the director has met the relevant standard under subsection A; or
    2. In connection with any other proceeding charging improper personal benefit to the director, whether or not involving action in his official capacity, in which he was adjudged liable on the basis that personal benefit was improperly received by him.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-3.1; 1968, c. 570; 1975, c. 500; 1979, c. 99; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765, in subsection A, deleted "of this section" following "subsection D" and added "the director" to the end; deleted "He" at the beginning of subdivisions A 1 and A 2; deleted "of subsection A of this section" at the end of subsection B; inserted "or upon a plea of nolo contendere or its equivalent" following "settlement or conviction" in subsection C; substituted "Unless ordered by a court under subsection C of § 13.1-700.1, a" for "A" at the beginning of subsection D; substituted "except for reasonable expenses incurred in connection with the proceeding if it is determined that the director has met the relevant standard under subsection A" for "in which the director was adjudged liable to the corporation" in subdivision D 1; and deleted subsection E.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection A, substituted "who is" for "made," substituted "the individual" for "he" in subdivision A 1, inserted the subdivision A 1 a designation and redesignated the remaining subdivisions accordingly; added subdivision A 2; in subsection D, inserted "or broader indemnification has been made permissible or obligatory as authorized by subsection C of § 13.1-704"; in subdivision D 1, deleted "reasonable" preceding "expenses"; and made stylistic changes.

Law review. - For article reviewing changes in Virginia corporate and business law from June 2001 through May 2002, see 37 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1 (2002).

§ 13.1-698. Mandatory indemnification.

Unless limited by its articles of incorporation, a corporation shall indemnify a director who was wholly successful, on the merits or otherwise, in the defense of any proceeding to which the director was a party because the director is or was a director of the corporation against expenses incurred by the director in connection with the proceeding.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-3.1; 1968, c. 570; 1975, c. 500; 1979, c. 99; 1985, c. 522; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote the section, which read: "Unless limited by its articles of incorporation, a corporation shall indemnify a director who entirely prevails in the defense of any proceeding to which he was a party because he is or was a director of the corporation against reasonable expenses incurred by him in connection with the proceeding."

Law review. - For annual survey article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 46 U. Rich. L. Rev. 41 (2011).

§ 13.1-699. Advance for expenses.

  1. A corporation may, before final disposition of a proceeding, advance funds to pay for or reimburse the expenses incurred in connection with the proceeding by a director who is a party to a proceeding because the individual is a director if the director delivers to the corporation a signed written undertaking to repay any funds advanced if (i) the director is not entitled to mandatory indemnification under § 13.1-698 and (ii) it is ultimately determined under § 13.1-700.1 or 13.1-701 that the director is not entitled to indemnification.
  2. The undertaking required by subsection A shall be an unlimited general obligation of the director but need not be secured and may be accepted without reference to the financial ability of the director to make repayment.
  3. Authorizations under this section shall be made by:
    1. The board of directors:
      1. If there are two or more disinterested directors, by a majority vote of all the disinterested directors, a majority of whom shall for such purpose constitute a quorum, or by a majority of the members of a committee consisting solely of two or more disinterested directors appointed by such a vote; or
      2. If there are fewer than two disinterested directors, by the vote necessary for action by the board of directors in accordance with subsection C of § 13.1-688, in which authorization directors who do not qualify as disinterested directors may participate; or
    2. By the shareholders, but shares owned by or voted under the control of a director who at the time does not qualify as a disinterested director may not be voted on the authorization.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-3.1; 1968, c. 570; 1975, c. 500; 1979, c. 99; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2010, c. 782; 2015, c. 611; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765 added "and" to the end of subdivision A 1; substituted the language beginning "any funds advanced" for "the advance it is ultimately determined that he did not meet the standard of conduct; and" in subdivision A 2; deleted subdivision A 3; deleted "of subsection A of this section" following "by subsection A 2" in subsection B; in subsection C, substituted "Authorizations" for "Determinations and" at the beginning, and substituted "by" for "in the manner specified in § 13.701" at the end; and added subdivisions C 1 through C 2.

The 2010 amendments. - The 2010 amendment by c. 782 inserted "signed" preceding "written" in subdivisions A 1 and A 2.

The 2015 amendments. - The 2015 amendment by c. 611 deleted former subdivision A 1, which read "The director furnishes the corporation a signed written statement of his good faith belief that he has met the standard of conduct described in § 13.1-697" and made related changes; substituted "subsection A" for "subdivision A 2" in subsection B; and made stylistic changes.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote subsection A; in subsection B, substituted "the financial ability of the director" for "financial ability"; in subsection C, deleted "of payments" preceding "under this"; in subdivision C 1 a, inserted "consisting solely"; and in subdivision C 1 b, inserted "of directors" following "board"; and made stylistic changes.

§ 13.1-700.

Repealed by Acts 1987, cc. 59, 257.

Cross references. - As to limitation on liability of officers and directors, see § 13.1-692.1.

As to court orders for advances, reimbursement or indemnification, see § 13.1-700.1.

§ 13.1-700.1. Court orders for advance, reimbursement, or indemnification.

  1. An individual who is a party to a proceeding because he is a director of the corporation may apply for indemnification or an advance of expenses to the court conducting the proceeding or to another court of competent jurisdiction. After receipt of an application and after giving any notice it considers necessary, the court shall:
    1. Order indemnification if the court determines that the director is entitled to mandatory indemnification under § 13.1-698;
    2. Order indemnification or advance for expenses if the court determines that the director is entitled to indemnification or advance for expenses pursuant to a provision authorized by § 13.1-704; or
    3. Order indemnification or advance for expenses if the court determines, in view of all the relevant circumstances, that it is fair and reasonable (i) to indemnify the director or (ii) to advance expenses to the director, even if, in the case of clause (i) or (ii), the director has not met the relevant standard of conduct set forth in subsection A of § 13.1-697, failed to comply with § 13.1-699, or was adjudged liable in a proceeding referred to in subsection D of § 13.1-697, but if the director was adjudged so liable, indemnification shall be limited to expenses incurred in connection with the proceeding.
  2. If the court determines that the director is entitled to indemnification under subdivision A 1 or to indemnification or advance for expenses under subdivision A 2, it shall also order the corporation to pay the director's expenses incurred in connection with obtaining court-ordered indemnification or advance for expenses. If the court determines that the director is entitled to indemnification or advance for expenses under subdivision A 3, it may also order the corporation to pay the director's expenses to obtain court-ordered indemnification or advance for expenses.
  3. Neither (i) the failure of the corporation, including its board of directors, its independent legal counsel and its shareholders, to have made a determination prior to the commencement of any action permitted by this section that the applying director is entitled to receive an advance, reimbursement, or indemnification nor (ii) the determination by the corporation, including its board of directors, its independent legal counsel and its shareholders, that the applying director is not entitled to receive an advance, reimbursement, or indemnification shall create a presumption to that effect or otherwise of itself be a defense to that director's application for an advance for expenses, reimbursement, or indemnification.

(1987, cc. 59, 257; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

Cross references. - As to indemnification under the Virginia Business Trust Act, see § 13.1-1230.

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765, in subsection A, deleted "or was" preceding "a director of" and substituted "the" for "a" following "a director of."

§ 13.1-701. Determination and authorization of indemnification.

  1. A corporation may not indemnify a director under § 13.1-697 unless authorized for a specific proceeding after a determination has been made that indemnification of the director is permissible because the director has met the relevant standard of conduct set forth in § 13.1-697.
  2. The determination shall be made:
    1. If there are two or more disinterested directors, by the board of directors by a majority vote of all the disinterested directors, a majority of whom shall for such purpose constitute a quorum, or by a majority of the members of a committee of two or more disinterested directors appointed by such a vote;
    2. By special legal counsel:
      1. Selected in the manner prescribed in subdivision 1; or
      2. If there are fewer than two disinterested directors, selected by the board of directors, in which selection directors who do not qualify as disinterested directors may participate; or
    3. By the shareholders, but shares owned by or voted under the control of a director who at the time does not qualify as a disinterested director may not be voted on the determination.
  3. Authorization of indemnification shall be made in the same manner as the determination that indemnification is permissible, except that if there are fewer than two disinterested directors or if the determination is made by special legal counsel, authorization of indemnification shall be made by those entitled to select special legal counsel under subdivision B 2.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-3.1; 1968, c. 570; 1975, c. 500; 1979, c. 99; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765, in subsection A, deleted "in the circumstances" following "is permissible" and inserted "relevant" preceding "standard"; in subdivision B 1, added "If there are two or more disinterested directors" at the beginning and deleted "a quorum consisting of directors not at," inserted "all," and deleted "time parties to the proceeding"; rewrote subdivision B 2 and redesignated it as part of subdivision B 1; redesignated former subdivision B 3 as present subdivision B 2; in present subdivision B 2 a, deleted "by the board of directors or its committee" at the beginning, and substituted "in subdivision 1" for "in subdivisions 1 and 2"; rewrote present subdivision B 2 b; in present subdivision B 3, substituted "a director who at the time does not quality as a disinterested director" for "of directors who are at the time parties to the preceding"; and in subsection C, deleted "and evaluation as to reasonableness of expenses" following "Authorization of indemnification," inserted "there are fewer than two disinterested directors or if" preceding "the determination is made," deleted "and evaluation as to reasonableness of expenses" preceding "shall be made by those entitled," and substituted "subdivision B 2 to select counsel" for "subdivision 3 b 2 of subsection B of this section to select counsel" at the end.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection A, substituted "for a specific proceeding" for "in the specific case," and substituted "the director" for "he"; in subdivision B 2 a, deleted "of this subsection"; and in subsection C, substituted "entitled to select special legal counsel under subdivision B 2" for "entitled under subdivision B 2 to select counsel."

Law review. - For article reviewing changes in Virginia corporate and business law from June 2001 through May 2002, see 37 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1 (2002).

§ 13.1-702. Advance for expenses and indemnification for officers.

Unless limited by a corporation's articles of incorporation:

  1. An officer of the corporation who is a party to a proceeding because he is an officer is entitled to mandatory indemnification under § 13.1-698 and is entitled to apply for court-ordered advance or reimbursement of expenses and indemnification under § 13.1-700.1, in each case to the same extent as a director; and
  2. The corporation may indemnify and advance expenses under this article to an officer who is a party to a proceeding because the individual is an officer to the same extent as to a director.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-3.1; 1968, c. 570; 1975, c. 500; 1979, c. 99; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765 deleted "employee, or agent" following "to an officer" in subdivision 2.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subdivision 1, inserted "who is a party to a proceeding because he is an officer" and inserted "advance or reimbursement of expenses and"; and in subdivision 2, substituted "who is a party to a proceeding because the individual is an officer" for "of the corporation."

§ 13.1-703. Insurance.
