The directors' difficulty arises when they violate the law and carry on the business instead of liquidating it. They then become personally liable. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531 (4th Cir. 1988).

Liability of directors and officers for actions taken after termination of corporate existence. - Upon a corporation's dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) by operation of law under this section, there is no corporation at all, and any actions performed by the directors or officers not looking to the dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) of the corporation should be deemed individual actions with concomitant individual liability therefor. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

Any actions performed by the directors or officers after dissolution, if not related to the process of winding up the corporation's affairs, should be deemed individual actions, with concomitant individual liability therefor. If an entity is no corporation at all, the individuals who conduct its affairs must be personally liable for their acts. Hudgins v. IRS, 132 Bankr. 115 (E.D. Va. 1991), modified, 967 F.2d 973 (4th Cir. 1992).

This section, the Virginia corporate dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) statute, by its terms requires a finding of personal responsibility on the part of the corporate directors for any liability created by any normal continuance of the corporate business after dissolution (now termination of corporate existence). Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

District court erred in dismissing lessor's claim for breach of fiduciary duty for conduct engaged in before January 1, 2000; the directors' duties as trustees in liquidation attached only upon termination of the corporate existence. Orix Credit Alliance, Inc. v. Young Express, Inc.,, 2002 U.S. App. LEXIS 17602 (4th Cir. Aug. 22, 2002).

Failure to maintain corporate formalities. - On appeal from an equitable distribution of the parties' assets, an accounting practice's sloppy corporate recordkeeping allowed the trial court to treat it as a partnership; further, such finding was inconsistent with allowing stock ownership to govern the percentage of the accounting practice that the court classified as a husband's, or the percentage of the husband's interest in the accounting practice classified as marital property. Scott v. Scott, No. 2422-06-1, 2007 Va. App. LEXIS 454 (Ct. of Appeals Dec. 18, 2007).

Because an accounting practice's sloppy corporate recordkeeping allowed the trial court to treat it as a partnership, the court did not abuse its discretion in awarding attorney's fees to a wife based on the entity's defiance of her subpoena duces tecum, which resulted in unnecessary discovery expenses. Scott v. Scott, No. 2422-06-1, 2007 Va. App. LEXIS 454 (Ct. of Appeals Dec. 18, 2007).

Burden on directors as trustees to produce accurate accounts of assets and affairs of trust created by this section and to prove any charges or other debts which they wish to advance to limit their liability. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531 (4th Cir. 1988).

When they breach their fiduciary duties as trustees directors incur personal liability to beneficiaries of trust created by this section. Section 13.1-754 provides that such liability, once incurred, is not discharged by the reinstatement of the corporation. Defendants breached their fiduciary duties, by using the trust res for operation of the business in violation of the statute instead of paying pre-existing obligations owed and for that reason they were personally liable for the damages caused by their breach of trust. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531 (4th Cir. 1988).

Directors and officers not relieved of liability by subsequent reinstatement. - Under this section and § 13.1-754, the managing officers and directors of a corporation incurred personal liability as "employers" under the federal Occupational Safety and Health Act (29 U.S.C. § 651 et seq.) for violations between the dates of the corporation's dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) under this section and reinstatement under § 13.1-754, and for the penalty assessed because of such violations, and the subsequent reinstatement of the corporate charter did not relieve them of such liability. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Liability of director for actions. - Under § 13.1-752 A, corporate property passed to the sole director of a corporation automatically as of the day the corporation's existence ceased, entitling a purchaser to specific performance of a sales contract involving the corporate property where the sole director had signed the sales contract and was bound, in equity, to complete the sale. Lifta Enters. v. Huh, 64 Va. Cir. 40, 2004 Va. Cir. LEXIS 20 (Fairfax County 2004).

Corporation that failed to wind up was estopped to deny its existence. - Corporation that was automatically dissolved in 2000 for failure to pay registration fees under § 13.1-752, but that continued to operate and hold itself out as a corporation well into 2005, when it obtained a loan from a bank for installing a swimming pool, was estopped to deny its existence or its liability for the loan on the grounds that its corporate status had been terminated. First Cmty. Bank, N.A. v. Cmty. Youth Ctr., 81 Va. Cir. 416, 2010 Va. Cir. LEXIS 307 (Greensville County Dec. 20, 2010).

Officers' action not consistent with winding up. - There is no evidence that a swimming pool was being installed at a youth community center in order to help dispose of the community center to an outside creditor or to distribute the property among the shareholders. Therefore, under §§ 13.1-745 and 13.1-752, the officers of the youth center could not, while acting as trustees in liquidation, have actual or apparent authority to grant a deed of trust to the bank for such a purpose once the youth center's corporate existence had ceased to exist for failure to pay registration fees. First Cmty. Bank, N.A. v. Cmty. Youth Ctr., 81 Va. Cir. 416, 2010 Va. Cir. LEXIS 307 (Greensville County Dec. 20, 2010).

§ 13.1-753. Involuntary termination of corporate existence.

  1. The corporate existence of a corporation may be terminated involuntarily by order of the Commission when it finds that the corporation (i) has continued to exceed or abuse the authority conferred upon it by law; (ii) has failed to maintain a registered office or a registered agent in this Commonwealth as required by law; (iii) has failed to file any document required by this chapter to be filed with the Commission; or (iv) has been convicted for a violation of 8 U.S.C. § 1324a(f), as amended, for actions of its officers and directors constituting a pattern or practice of employing unauthorized aliens in the Commonwealth. Upon termination, the properties and affairs of the corporation shall pass automatically to its directors as trustees in liquidation. The trustees then shall proceed to collect the assets of the corporation; sell, convey and dispose of such of its properties as are not to be distributed in kind to its shareholders; pay, satisfy and discharge its liabilities and obligations; and do all other acts required to liquidate its business and affairs. After paying or adequately providing for the payment of all its obligations, the trustees shall distribute the remainder of its assets, either in cash or in kind, among its shareholders according to their respective rights and interests. A corporation whose existence is terminated pursuant to clause (iv) shall not be eligible for reinstatement for a period of not less than one year.
  2. Any corporation convicted of the offense listed in clause (iv) of subsection A shall immediately report such conviction to the Commission and file with the Commission an authenticated copy of the judgment or record of conviction.
  3. Before entering any such order the Commission shall issue a rule against the corporation giving it an opportunity to be heard and show cause why such an order should not be entered. The Commission may issue the rule on its own motion or on motion of the Attorney General.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-93; 1956, c. 428; 1958, c. 506; 1968, c. 116; 1975, cc. 88, 500; 1985, c. 522; 1991, c. 310; 2008, cc. 588, 770.)

The 2008 amendments. - The 2008 amendments by cc. 588 and 770 are identical, and in subsection A, inserted clause (iv), added the last sentence, and made related changes; added subsection B; and redesignated former subsection B as subsection C.

Editor's note. - Some of the cases below were decided under prior law.

CASE NOTES

How forfeiture of corporate franchise can be effected. - The forfeiture of corporate franchises can be effected only by the State or private persons under statutory authority. Elliott's Knob Iron, Steel & Coal Co. v. SCC, 123 Va. 63, 96 S.E. 353 (1918).

Cannot be done collaterally. - A cause of forfeiture of the charter of a corporation, however great, cannot be taken advantage of collaterally or incidentally or in any other mode than by a direct proceeding for that purpose on behalf of the government. Pixley v. Roanoke Nav. Co., 75 Va. 320 (1881); Dismal Swamp R.R. v. John L. Roper Lumber Co., 114 Va. 537, 77 S.E. 598 (1913). See Colonial Inv. Co. v. Cherrydale Cement Block Co., 194 Va. 454, 73 S.E.2d 419 (1952).

Applicable to any corporation whose activities are outside its charter. - This section is simply the statutory mechanism by which the Attorney General initiates Commission revocation of the charter of any corporation which has abused the Commonwealth's permission to use the corporate form of doing business for purposes set forth in that charter. The provision applies with equal force to any corporation whose activities are outside the permissible ambit of its charter. Croatan Books, Inc. v. Virginia, 574 F. Supp. 880 (E.D. Va. 1983).

Distribution of obscene materials. - Obscene material enjoys no protection under U.S. Const., Amend. I. Therefore, in no way could a corporation claim that the Commonwealth authorized it to purvey obscene materials by allowing it to distribute novelties, magazines, books and newspapers. Clearly, in excess of 60 felony convictions for doing so could reasonably be considered an abuse of its charter. Croatan Books, Inc. v. Virginia, 574 F. Supp. 880 (E.D. Va. 1983).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Transfer of stock after termination. - Decedent had the right to transfer 100 shares of stock to his son even though the corporation's existence had been terminated where, under subsection A of § 13.1-753, it appeared that the decedent had an expectation of future distribution, and there was no evidence that the corporation's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or agreement restricted the transfer of shares. Square Deal Demolition, Inc. v. Doxie, 74 Va. Cir. 441, 2008 Va. Cir. LEXIS 65 (Norfolk 2008).

§ 13.1-754. Reinstatement of a corporation that has ceased to exist.

  1. A corporation that has ceased to exist pursuant to this article may apply to the Commission for reinstatement within five years thereafter unless the corporate existence was terminated by order of the Commission (i) upon a finding that the corporation has continued to exceed or abuse the authority conferred upon it by law or (ii) entered pursuant to § 13.1-749 and the circuit court's decree directing dissolution contains no provision for reinstatement of corporate existence.
  2. To have its corporate existence reinstated, the corporation shall provide the Commission with the following:
    1. An application for reinstatement, which shall include the identification number issued by the Commission to the corporation, and which may be in the form of a letter signed by an officer or director of the corporation, or which may be by affidavit signed by an agent of any shareholder's interests stating that after diligent search by such agent, no officer or director can be found;
    2. A reinstatement fee of $100;
    3. All annual registration fees and penalties that were due before the corporation ceased to exist and that would have been assessed or imposed to the date of reinstatement if the corporation's existence had not been terminated;
    4. An annual report for the calendar year that corresponds to the calendar year of the latest annual registration fee that was assessed or that would have been assessed to the date of reinstatement;
    5. If the name of the corporation does not comply with the provisions of § 13.1-630 at the time of reinstatement, articles of amendment to the articles of incorporation to change the corporation's name to a name that satisfies the provisions of § 13.1-630, with the fee required by this chapter for the filing of articles of amendment; and
    6. If the corporation's registered agent has filed a statement of resignation and a new registered agent has not been appointed, a statement of change pursuant to § 13.1-635.
  3. If the corporation complies with the provisions of this section, the Commission shall enter an order of reinstatement of corporate existence. Upon entry of the order, the corporate existence shall be deemed to have continued from the date of termination as if the termination had never occurred, and any liability incurred by the corporation or a director, officer, or other agent after the termination and before the reinstatement is determined as if the termination of the corporation's existence had never occurred.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-92; 1956, c. 428; 1958, c. 564; 1975, c. 88; 1978, c. 804; 1980, c. 654; 1982, c. 648; 1984, c. 69; 1985, c. 522; 1986, c. 234; 1988, c. 405; 2004, c. 601; 2005, c. 379; 2006, c. 663; 2015, c. 623.)

The 2004 amendments. - The 2004 amendment by c. 601 substituted "and any liability incurred by the corporation or a director, officer, or other agent after termination of corporate existence and before the reinstatement shall be determined as if the termination of corporate existence had never occurred" for "except that reinstatement shall have no effect on any question of personal liability of the directors, officers or agents in respect to the period between termination of corporate existence and reinstatement" in the next-to-last sentence.

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 379, effective March 21, 2005, in the last sentence, substituted "is not distinguishable upon the records of the Commission," for "has been assumed or reserved or registered by any other person" and added "to a name that is distinguishable upon the records of the Commission."

The 2006 amendments. - The 2006 amendment by c. 663 inserted the clause (i) designation and added clause (ii).

The 2015 amendments. - The 2015 amendment by c. 623 rewrote the section.

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, § 275.

CASE NOTES

Legislative intent. - The legislature intended that once a corporation achieves reinstatement, its corporate status relates back to the date of its termination and it is as if the corporation had never been terminated and debtor's action to achieve reinstatement after the filing of the petition for Chapter 11 supports its eligibility for Chapter 11 relief since, in the eyes of the State, it has been a corporation all along. In re Wine Farms, Inc., 94 Bankr. 410 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1988).

Director's liability. - People dealing with a corporation are obliged to look to the corporation for satisfaction of their claims and only in extraordinary circumstances are directors liable for corporate debts. Section 13.1-752 and this section must be construed in a manner consistent with the strong public policy of shielding directors from individual liability for corporate debt and these sections do not impose any liability for corporate debt on the directors simply because the corporation has been automatically dissolved. Even after dissolution, the directors are shielded from individual liability if they discharge the duties the statute places on them to marshal assets, pay pre-existing debts, and distribute the remaining funds, if any, to the shareholders. Moreover, the directors may temporarily continue the corporate business as an incident to its liquidation without incurring individual liability. The directors' difficulty arises when they violate the law and carry on the business instead of liquidating it. They then become personally liable. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531 (4th Cir. 1988).

Liability of directors for actions taken between termination of corporate existence and reinstatement. - This section, the Virginia reinstatement statute, does not relieve the directors, who have continued the corporate business, of individual liability for actions in the interim period between dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) and reinstatement. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

In an action for damages by an information technology company and its sole owner against a former partner, his wife, and their new corporation, the trial court did not err in refusing to strike all of plaintiffs' evidence because the information technology company's corporate existence was terminated during the time of the alleged wrong where the company's reinstatement following termination had the retroactive effect of placing it in a position as if its termination had never occurred. Syed v. Zh Techs., Inc., 280 Va. 58, 694 S.E.2d 625, 2010 Va. LEXIS 73 (2010).

Directors, etc., not relieved of liability by reinstatement. - Language of this section, the Virginia reinstatement statute, is quite clear that reinstatement has no effect on any question of personal liability of the directors. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

This section makes the revived corporation liable for any liabilities incurred in the interim period, but it declares at the same time, in unmistakable terms, that reinstatement will not relieve the directors of the personal liability they have already incurred by continuing the normal operations of the corporation during dissolution. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

Under § 13.1-752 and this section, the managing officers and directors of a corporation incurred personal liability as "employers" under the federal Occupational Safety and Health Act (29 U.S.C. § 651 et seq.) for violations between the dates of the corporation's dissolution under § 13.1-752 and reinstatement under this section, and for the penalty assessed because of such violations, and the subsequent reinstatement of the corporate charter did not relieve them of such liability. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law).

Where a party alleges that the business affairs of a dissolved corporation have been carried on by the acts of certain officers, directors, or agents of the dissolved corporation, then those officers, directors, or agents can be held personally liable for contracts entered on behalf of the dissolved corporation. Any such personal liability incurred because of acts done during the period of corporate dissolution is not relieved by the reinstatement of the corporation. McLean Bank v. Nelson, 232 Va. 420, 350 S.E.2d 651 (1986).

Upon dissolution directors become trustees of corporate assets. - Upon dissolution, the directors no longer function as directors of a corporation and § 13.1-752 provides that they become trustees in dissolution, the assets of the corporation automatically pass to them in their new capacity and this is the res of the trust they must administer. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531 (4th Cir. 1988).

Burden on directors as trustees to produce accurate accounts of assets and affairs of trust created by § 13.1-752 and to prove any charges or other debts which they wish to advance to limit their liability. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531 (4th Cir. 1988).

When they breach their fiduciary duties as trustees directors incur personal liability to beneficiaries of trust created by § 13.1-752 and this section provides that such liability, once incurred, is not discharged by the reinstatement of the corporation. Defendants breached their fiduciary duties, by using the trust res for operation of the business in violation of the statute instead of paying pre-existing obligations owed and for that reason they were personally liable for the damages caused by their breach of trust. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531 (4th Cir. 1988).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Effect on stock distribution. - Upon reinstatement of the corporation, the son became owner of the stock that decedent had transferred to him where the corporation was reinstated within five years of its termination and thus, it was deemed to have continued in existence from the termination date. Square Deal Demolition, Inc. v. Doxie, 74 Va. Cir. 441, 2008 Va. Cir. LEXIS 65 (Norfolk 2008).

§ 13.1-755. Survival of remedy after termination of corporate existence.

The termination of corporate existence shall not take away or impair any remedy available to or against the corporation or its directors, officers, or shareholders for any right or claim existing or any liability incurred prior to such termination. Any such action or proceeding by or against the corporation may be prosecuted or defended by the corporation in its corporate name. The shareholders, directors, and officers shall have power to take such corporate or other action as shall be appropriate to protect such remedy, right, or claim.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-101; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 made stylistic changes.

Law review. - For article surveying major developments between 1991 and 1992 that affect business and corporate law in Virginia, see "Business and Corporate Law," 26 U. Rich. L. Rev. 653 (1992).

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Abatement, Survival and Revival, § 16; 2C M.J. Bankruptcy, § 12; 4B M.J. Corporations, §§ 35, 262, 276, 277.

Editor's note. - Some of the cases below were decided under prior law.

CASE NOTES

Liberal construction. - The simplification of procedures and the complete reversal of the common-law rule of abatement of actions upon dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) are remedial measures entitled to a liberal construction to effectuate their purposes. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816 (4th Cir. 1962).

Strict construction. - Under the common law, once a corporation's existence was terminated, its capacity to sue, or to be sued, likewise was terminated, irrespective of when the cause of action arose. This section, however, partially changed the common-law rule. This section, being in derogation of the common law, therefore, must be strictly construed. Harris v. T.I., Inc., 243 Va. 63, 413 S.E.2d 605 (1992).

Application of Virginia statutes to foreign corporations. - As to application to foreign corporations of former § 13-70, providing for continuation of corporate existence for three years following dissolution of a corporation for the purpose of winding up its affairs, and former § 13-72, providing that dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) of a corporation should not abate any pending action against it, see Bardach Iron & Steel Co. v. Tenenbaum, 136 Va. 163, 118 S.E. 502 (1923); DuPont Eng'r Co. v. John P. Harvey Constr. Co., 156 Va. 582, 158 S.E. 891 (1931).

Section authorizes suits by or against corporation without limitation of time. - This section authorizes actions by or against a corporation, and in its corporate name, after dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) without a limitation of time. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816 (4th Cir. 1962).

Under this section, passage of time after the date of dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) is without significance, although general statutes of limitation referable to the accrual of the cause of action remain applicable. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816 (4th Cir. 1962).

And applies to corporations whose charters were revoked prior to its enactment. - This section applied to suits against corporations the charters of which had been revoked prior to the enactment of this section. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816 (4th Cir. 1962).

There was no retroactivity in the application of this section to corporations the charter of which had been revoked prior to the enactment of the section. It altered no substantive right; it only altered the procedure by which substantive rights may be judicially enforced. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816 (4th Cir. 1962).

Court order continuing authority of directors or appointing receiver is no longer necessary. - Under this section a court order continuing the authority of directors or appointing a receiver is no longer a prerequisite to the institution of an action against a corporation in dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) at any time. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816 (4th Cir. 1962).

Corporation not relieved of obligations by dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) after transfer of assets. - See Pepper v. Dixie Splint Coal Co., 165 Va. 179, 181 S.E. 406 (1935).

Pending action not abated. - See Shepherd v. Kress Box Co., 154 Va. 421, 153 S.E. 649 (1930).

Voluntary petition in bankruptcy contemplated by section. - The legislature contemplated a voluntary petition in bankruptcy as one of the means empowering officers, directors and shareholders of a dissolved corporation (now corporation which has ceased to exist), to proceed as is provided in this section in its corporate name. In re Rust Control, Inc., 1 Bankr. 303 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1979).

The filing of a voluntary petition in bankruptcy is one of the classic means of liquidating a defunct corporation, and the orderly processes of the bankruptcy statutes administered in the bankruptcy court protect the rights of all creditors in accordance with the validity and priorities of their respective claims and provide remedies for recovering property and voiding preferences which may have been granted some creditors. In re Rust Control, Inc., 1 Bankr. 303 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1979).

Claim survives termination of corporate existence. - A corporation which had been involuntarily dissolved (now corporation whose existence has been terminated) by the Commission had the capacity to seek a determination that its claim against a debtor was non-dischargeable in bankruptcy. Mining Env'ts, Inc. v. Staley, 43 Bankr. 374 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1984).

Liability for injury occurring after dissolution. - A corporation cannot escape liability where, although the injury plaintiff complains of is related to a product purchased from defendant corporation, prior to dissolution, the claim did not arise until the injury occurred and the injury asserted occurred after dissolution. That result would be inconsistent with the clear intent of this section to abrogate the common-law rule which absolves a corporation of any liability once that corporation is dissolved. Oliver v. AMC, 616 F. Supp. 714 (E.D. Va. 1985).

Absent an ulterior motive there is no basis for distinguishing between the eligibility of a debtor to file a Chapter 7 proceeding as opposed to a Chapter 11 proceeding when it has been terminated by the state. In re Wine Farms, Inc., 94 Bankr. 410 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1988).

A claim against a corporation must have existed or the liability of a corporation must have been incurred prior to the date of the corporation's termination in order for the claim or liability to survive the termination. Thus, where executor's cause of action did not arise until the accidental death of his decedent more than two years after corporation ceased to exist, the trial court correctly sustained corporation's demurrer. Harris v. T.I., Inc., 243 Va. 63, 413 S.E.2d 605 (1992).

Service of process upon president of a defunct corporation was proper, as this section expressly provides that a defunct corporation may be sued for liability incurred prior to the termination of its corporate existence, and since defendant defunct corporation could be sued as before, it could also be served with process as before. United States v. Moore, 698 F. Supp. 622 (E.D. Va. 1988).

Surety provided notice of proceedings. - Since a subcontractor had notice of proceedings against it, as well as the trial court's two orders compelling the subcontractor to make available a corporate officer to be deposed, and that knowledge was imputed to its surety; nonetheless, the fact that the subcontractor was a defunct corporation did not alleviate its responsibility to name an officer to be present for the deposition. Am. Safety Cas. Ins. Co. v. C.G. Mitchell Constr., 268 Va. 340, 601 S.E.2d 633, 2004 Va. LEXIS 129 (2004).

Applied in Giannotti v. Hamway, 239 Va. 14, 387 S.E.2d 725 (1990); In re Banks-Davis, 148 Bankr. 810 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1992).

§ 13.1-756.

Repealed by Acts 1988, c. 405.

Article 17.
Foreign Corporations.

§ 13.1-757. Authority to transact business required.

  1. A foreign corporation may not transact business in the Commonwealth until it obtains a certificate of authority from the Commission.
  2. The following activities, among others, do not constitute transacting business within the meaning of subsection A:
    1. Maintaining, defending, mediating, arbitrating, or settling any proceeding;
    2. Holding meetings of the board of directors or shareholders or carrying on other activities concerning internal corporate affairs;
    3. Maintaining accounts in financial institutions;
    4. Maintaining offices or agencies for the transfer, exchange, and registration of the corporation's own securities or maintaining trustees or depositories with respect to those securities;
    5. Selling through independent contractors;
    6. Soliciting or obtaining orders, by any means, if the orders require acceptance outside the Commonwealth before they become contracts;
    7. Creating or acquiring indebtedness, deeds of trust, or security interests in property;
    8. Securing or collecting debts or enforcing deeds of trust or security interests in property securing the debts, and holding, protecting, or maintaining property so acquired;
    9. Owning, protecting, and maintaining property;
    10. Conducting an isolated transaction that is completed within 30 consecutive days and that is not one in the course of similar transactions;
    11. For a period of less than 90 consecutive days, producing, directing, filming, crewing, or acting in motion picture feature films, television series, or commercials, or promotional films that are sent outside of the Commonwealth for processing, editing, marketing, and distribution;
    12. Serving, without more, as a general partner of, or as a partner in a partnership which is a general partner of, a domestic or foreign limited partnership that does not otherwise transact business in the Commonwealth; or
    13. Transacting business in interstate commerce.
  3. The list of activities in subsection B is not exhaustive.
  4. This section does not apply in determining the contacts or activities that may subject a foreign corporation to service of process, taxation, or regulation under the laws of the Commonwealth other than this chapter.
  5. The term "transacting business" as used in this section shall have no effect on personal jurisdiction under § 8.01-328.1.

(Code 1950, §§ 13.1-102 to 13.1-102.2; 1956, c. 428; 1962, c. 239; 1980, c. 630; 1985, c. 522; 1990, c. 428; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

Cross references. - As to registration and authority to transact business for financial institutions, see § 6.2-702. As to filing requirements for interstate branches of out-of-state banks, see Article 6 ( § 6.2-836 et seq.) of Chapter 8 of Title 6.2.

As to additional filing requirements for out-of-state banks, see § 6.2-840.

As to constitutional authority, see Va. Const., Art. IX, § 5.

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted "the Commonwealth" for "this Commonwealth" in subsection A and subdivision B 12; deleted "of this section" following "subsection A" in subsection B; substituted "that does" for "which does" in subdivision B 12; deleted "of this section" following "subsection B" in subsection C; and made minor stylistic changes.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote this Code section.

Law review. - For article, "The New Virginia Stock Corporation Act: A Primer," see 20 U. Rich. L. Rev. 67 (1985).

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, § 290; 15 M.J. Railroads, § 3.

Editor's note. - Many of the cases below were decided under prior law.

CASE NOTES

Constitutionality. - Former § 163 of the Constitution precluded foreign corporations from exercising their functions in this State, except upon compliance with its laws, and expressly authorized the General Assembly to discriminate against them. The General Assembly could exclude foreign corporations from exercising their functions within this State, subject only to the inhibition of the federal Constitution. Knights of KKK v. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122 (1924).

Transactions constituting "transacting business." - Transacting business in the State by a foreign corporation pursuant to this section and § 13.1-758 imports the transaction of its ordinary and customary business herein. Conversely, business transactions of such corporation within the State which are not a part of its ordinary business but instead are merely incidental thereto are insufficient to constitute "transacting business" pursuant to this section and § 13.1-758. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538 (E.D. Va. 1977).

A corporation's sole connection to Virginia as a passive investor in notes secured by real estate located in the Commonwealth, did not constitute the transaction of business in the state. Peterson v. Cooley, 142 F.3d 181 (4th Cir. 1998).

Business need not be commercial. - Doing business, as used in the statutes with reference to foreign corporations, is not confined to commercial or manufacturing functions only, but the exercise of its corporate functions by any foreign corporation within this State constitutes transacting business here within the meaning of the statutes. Knights of KKK v. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122 (1924).

Thus, social business is included. - A patriotic, secret, social, benevolent, and foreign corporation, which established local organizations, initiated members and furnished them with paraphernalia, was exercising its functions and powers within this State, under the provisions of the statutes, and was therefore subject to the provisions thereof. Knights of KKK v. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122 (1924).

A foreign corporation which solicits members, organizes lodges, distributes regalia, collects fees, and makes such contracts as are involved in or incidental to these acts, is protected under the provisions of law of this State, and the indirect connection with anything which could be fairly held to be interstate commerce is too remote to relieve it from the provisions of the statutes relating to foreign corporations. Knights of KKK v. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122 (1924).

Illustrations of "doing business." - The erection and installation within this State, by a foreign corporation, of a complete railway signal system, involving the employment of labor, skilled and unskilled, the stringing of wires, the construction of concrete foundations, and the erection and painting of signal mechanisms, all to be performed in this State, constitutes doing business in this State. General Ry. Signal Co. v. Commonwealth, 118 Va. 301, 87 S.E. 598 (1916), aff'd, 246 U.S. 500, 38 S. Ct. 360, 62 L. Ed. 854 (1918).

A foreign corporation which made a contract for the sale, installation and erection of certain gas machines and equipments in this State, involving extensive construction work, was doing business in this State, and therefore liable under § 13.1-758 for having failed to take out license therefor; the essence of the undertaking was the construction engaged in, the sale being a mere incident thereto. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC v. Western Gas Constr. Co., 11 Va. L. Reg. (n.s.) 737 (1926).

The making of a contract out of this State by a foreign corporation, by which title to a tract of land within the State is acquired by such corporation, is not doing business in the State, so as to render a director of the company liable for its debts under § 13.1-758, although the object of the purchase be to engage in mining in the State at a subsequent time. Goldsberry v. Carter, 100 Va. 438, 41 S.E. 858 (1902).

A manufacturer which shipped goods on consignment to its exclusive distributor in Virginia, and, when the goods were sold by the distributor on conditional sales contracts, accepted assignment of the conditional sales contracts from the distributor, was not, under the facts, doing business in this State so as to subject it to the requirements of this article. Rock-Ola Mfg. Corp. v. Wertz, 249 F.2d 813 (4th Cir. 1957).

Entering into a purchase agreement for the sale of land to be used as a future manufacturing site does not constitute "transacting business" within the statutory meaning of this section or § 13.1-758. Neither do the incidentals associated therewith, such as negotiating with and entering into construction contracts with an architectural firm, a general construction firm and a real estate development and investment firm such as plaintiff. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538 (E.D. Va. 1977).

Although plaintiff building and loan association was neither "doing business" nor was it authorized to "do business" in Virginia in accordance with Virginia law, the fact is that, lawfully, it had a substantial number of customers in Virginia and had made a number of loans secured by the pledge of real estate in this jurisdiction. In the context of an alleged misappropriation of a trade name, the reality of a building and loan association's "doing business" ought to be considered by the court. Kyhos v. Perpetual Sav. & Loan Ass'n, 480 F.2d 204 (4th Cir. 1973).

Trademarks. - Although both the Georgia and Virginia Southern Christian Leadership Conferences (SCLC) operated in Virginia without proper authority, the Breakaway SCLC's registration of the service/trademarks did not defeat their continuous common-law use of the contested marks under § 59.1-92.3; therefore, the trial court's judgment that the Georgia SCLC and Virginia SCLC had a superior claim to the marks was not erroneous. SCLC v. Shannon, 270 Va. 104, 613 S.E.2d 596, 2005 Va. LEXIS 61 (2005).

Interstate commerce and the license tax. - The test to determine whether a foreign corporation transacts such intrastate business as can be reached by state license tax is whether its domestic business is substantial in its essence, and whether it may be reasonably separated from its interstate commerce. The question does not depend upon a comparison of its intrastate with its interstate commerce. Dalton Adding Mach. Co. v. Commonwealth, 118 Va. 563, 88 S.E. 167 (1916), aff'd, 246 U.S. 498, 38 S. Ct. 361, 62 L. Ed. 851 (1918).

Applied in Holliday v. Scansea, Inc., 232 Va. 316, 350 S.E.2d 607 (1986).

OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

Foreign business trust need not obtain certificate of authority before filing fictitious name certificate. - A foreign business trust is not required to obtain a certificate of authority before filing a fictitious name certificate as a foreign business trust is not included within definitions of business entities required to obtain either a certificate of authority or certificate of registration. See opinion of Attorney General to The Honorable John T. Frey, Clerk, Circuit Court of Fairfax County, 00-039, 2000 Va. AG LEXIS 40 (6/12/00).

§ 13.1-758. Consequences of transacting business without authority.

  1. A foreign corporation transacting business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority may not maintain a proceeding in any court in the Commonwealth until it obtains a certificate of authority.
  2. The successor to a foreign corporation that transacted business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority and the assignee of a cause of action arising out of that business may not maintain a proceeding based on that cause of action in any court in the Commonwealth until the foreign corporation or its successor obtains a certificate of authority.
  3. A court may stay a proceeding commenced by a foreign corporation, its successor, or assignee until it determines whether the foreign corporation or its successor requires a certificate of authority. If it so determines, the court shall further stay the proceeding until the foreign corporation or its successor obtains the certificate.
  4. If a foreign corporation transacts business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority, each officer, director, and employee who does any of such business in the Commonwealth knowing that a certificate of authority is required shall be liable for a penalty of not less than $500 and not more than $5,000. Any such penalty may be imposed by the Commission or by any court in the Commonwealth before which an action against the corporation may lie, after the corporation and the individual have been given notice and an opportunity to be heard.
  5. Notwithstanding subsections A and B, the failure of a foreign corporation to obtain a certificate of authority does not impair the validity of its corporate acts or prevent it from defending any proceeding in the Commonwealth.
  6. Suits, actions, and proceedings may be begun against a foreign corporation that transacts business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority by serving process on any director, officer, or agent of the corporation doing such business, or, if none can be found, on the clerk of the Commission or on the corporation in any other manner permitted by law. If any foreign corporation transacts business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority, it shall by transacting such business be deemed to have thereby appointed the clerk of the Commission as an agent for service of process upon the foreign corporation. Service upon the clerk shall be made in accordance with § 12.1-19.1.

(Code 1950, §§ 13-218, 13.1-119; 1956, c. 428; 1981, c. 320; 1985, c. 522; 1986, c. 571; 1990, c. 325; 1991, c. 672; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734.)

Cross references. - As to unlicensed public adjusters, see Article 3 ( § 38.2-812 et seq.) of Chapter 8 of Title 38.2.

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted "the Commonwealth" for "this Commonwealth" throughout; deleted "of this section" following "B" in subsection E; in subsection F, inserted "or on the corporation in any other manner permitted by law" in the first sentence and in the third sentence, inserted "upon the clerk" and deleted "on the clerk" following "made"; and made minor stylistic changes.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection F, substituted "as an agent" for "its attorney," and inserted "upon the foreign corporation" following "of process."

Law review. - For 1987 survey of Virginia business and corporate law, see 21 U. Rich. L. Rev. 645 (1987).

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Attachment and Garnishment, § 11; 4B M.J. Corporations, §§ 290, 297; 11B M.J. Jurisdiction, § 15.

Editor's note. - Some of the cases below were decided under prior law.

CASE NOTES

Liberal construction of former law. - See Knott Corp. v. Furman, 163 F.2d 199 (4th Cir.), cert. denied, 332 U.S. 809, 68 S. Ct. 111, 92 L. Ed. 387 (1947).

Engaging in business subjects foreign corporation to jurisdiction of state courts. - When a foreign corporation engages in the privilege of doing business in Virginia, it enjoys the benefits and protection of the laws of this Commonwealth. It thereby subjects itself to the jurisdiction of the courts of this State for the purpose of litigating liabilities created during its stay here. Eure v. Morgan Jones & Co., 195 Va. 678, 79 S.E.2d 862 (1954).

Defendant was a Massachusetts corporation with the principal office in New York. It had not been domesticated in Virginia, had no resident agent here, and had not designated the Secretary of the Commonwealth (now the Clerk of the Commission) as its agent for service of process. Under such circumstances, it was necessary that defendant be engaged in business in the State in order to validate service upon it under this section which provides for service only if a corporation is so engaged. Carnegie v. Art Metal Constr. Co., 191 Va. 136, 60 S.E.2d 17 (1950).

A corporation which engages in business in the Commonwealth so as to enjoy the protections of its laws thereby subjects itself to the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth. Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868 (E.D. Va. 1983).

Which is not defeated by withdrawal from State. - A foreign corporation which does business in Virginia without domesticating or appointing a statutory agent nevertheless constitutes the Clerk of the Commission its agent for service of process. It may not, by withdrawing from the State, defeat an action growing out of business done in Virginia, and such action may be begun by substituted service. Eure v. Morgan Jones & Co., 195 Va. 678, 79 S.E.2d 862 (1954).

The only prerequisite of this section is that the corporation sought to be served must be transacting business within the Commonwealth. Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868 (E.D. Va. 1983).

There is no discernible distinction between the terms "transacting business" and "doing business." Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868 (E.D. Va. 1983).

The terms "transacting business" and "doing business" are used interchangeably by Virginia courts to describe the same action. The United States District Court, Eastern District of Virginia, will do the same. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538 (E.D. Va. 1977).

Transactions constituting "transacting business." - Transacting business in the State by a foreign corporation pursuant to § 13.1-757 and this section imports the transaction of its ordinary and customary business herein. Conversely, business transactions of such corporation within the State which are not a part of its ordinary business but instead are merely incidental thereto are insufficient to constitute "transacting business" pursuant to § 13.1-757 and this section. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538 (E.D. Va. 1977).

Entering into a purchase agreement for the sale of land to be used as a future manufacturing site does not constitute "transacting business" within the statutory meaning of § 13.1-757 or this section. Neither do the incidentals associated therewith, such as negotiating with and entering into construction contracts with an architectural firm, a general construction firm and a real estate development and investment firm such as plaintiff. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538 (E.D. Va. 1977).

Merely ordering products or supplies in a forum state is not sufficient to find that a foreign corporation is transacting business necessitating procurement of a certificate of authority. Questech, Inc. v. Liteco, AG, 735 F. Supp. 187 (E.D. Va. 1990).

Where the tortious injury does not arise out of in-state activities, a stronger showing of contacts between the defendant and the forum is required. The "regularity test" is applied in a situation where the cause of action did not arise from the in-state activity. The regularity test looks toward the continuity of business activity within the forum. Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868 (E.D. Va. 1983).

Compliance with section before judgment is sufficient. - "Maintain" means a continuation of the proceeding already begun, and compliance with the requirements of this section before judgment is sufficient to entitle the corporation to continue its prosecution. Video Eng'r Co. v. Foto-Video Elecs., Inc., 207 Va. 1027, 154 S.E.2d 7 (1967).

Compliance with this section by a foreign corporation transacting business in this State after it has commenced an attachment proceeding is sufficient to enable it to continue the action. Video Eng'r Co. v. Foto-Video Elecs., Inc., 207 Va. 1027, 154 S.E.2d 7 (1967).

Construction of prohibition against noncomplying corporations maintaining suits in state courts. - The prohibition against noncomplying corporations maintaining law suits in Virginia courts is not so much a defense available to a litigant's adversaries, and therefore plausibly waivable, but it is rather an absolute bar to the offender's use of the courts to press its claim until compliance with the statutes is effected. Moore v. Northern Homes of Pa., Inc., 80 F.R.D. 278 (W.D. Va. 1978).

Effect of service on the Secretary of the Commonwealth. - Serving the Secretary of the Commonwealth pursuant to § 8.01-329 does not comply with the requirements of this section. Service upon the Secretary instead of the Clerk of the Corporation Commission is ineffective. The defect is cured, however, by § 8.01-288 which states that "[e]xcept for process commencing actions for divorce or annulment of marriage, process which has reached the person to whom it is directed within the time prescribed by law, if any, shall be sufficient although not served or accepted as provided in this chapter." Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868 (E.D. Va. 1983).

Agent's authority to accept service may be implied. - The fact that the person on whom service was effected is not the registered agent of a foreign corporation is not dispositive as an agent's authority to accept service may be implied in fact. Davies v. Jobs & Adverts Online, GmbH, 94 F. Supp. 2d 719, 2000 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 6488 (E.D. Va. 2000).

Service on attorney insufficient. - Where the plaintiff presented no evidence to establish that the defendant, a foreign corporation, either explicitly or implicitly authorized its local counsel to accept service of process or that the attorney ever represented to anyone that he had such authority, service on the attorney was insufficient. Davies v. Jobs & Adverts Online, GmbH, 94 F. Supp. 2d 719, 2000 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 6488 (E.D. Va. 2000).

Application to diversity actions. - This section applies not only to state court actions, but also to diversity actions in federal courts sitting in Virginia. Consolidated Eng'g Co. v. Southern Steel Co., 88 F.R.D. 233 (E.D. Va. 1980).

Enjoining Commission. - The threatened enforcement of former § 13-218, by the proper officers, will not be enjoined at the instance of a corporation which asserts that its business within the State is wholly interstate, where it is not claimed that the statute is unconstitutional, but only that it may be enforced in such a way as to violate the commerce clause of the federal Constitution. The corporation has an adequate remedy at law in its right to raise the constitutional question if proceedings are taken against it, or to recover the license fee if it pays it under protest. Dalton Adding Mach. Co. v. SCC, 236 U.S. 699, 35 S. Ct. 480, 59 L. Ed. 797 (1915), aff'g, 213 F. 889 (E.D. Va. 1913).

When corporation barred from suing in federal court. - If the doors of a state's courts are properly shut to a foreign corporation, it is settled that the corporation is likewise barred from suing, on the basis of diversity of citizenship, in a federal court sitting in that state. Rock-Ola Mfg. Corp. v. Wertz, 249 F.2d 813 (4th Cir. 1957).

Personal liability where conducting business without authority. - Under this section, had corporation conducted business in Virginia without authority to do so, defendant would have been personally liable on the notes as an officer and director of a foreign corporation. Avocet Dev. Corp. v. McLean Bank, 234 Va. 658, 364 S.E.2d 757 (1988) (decided under prior law).

While plaintiff argued that failure to comply with this statute must make a final judgment obtained by an "offender" void, even though he never raised this objection prior to judgment, the statute itself does not so provide and although the Virginia Supreme Court has held that a party can be required to obtain a certificate of authority to operate in the state prior to proceeding in ongoing litigation, it has never been held that this can be the basis for disregarding a final judgment. Quarles v. Miller, 86 F.3d 55 (4th Cir. 1996).

Collateral attack disallowed where violation of statute was not raised before. - Where the plaintiff had a chance to raise the certificate of authority issue under this section with the trial court or on appeal with the Virginia Supreme Court, and he failed to do so, absent fraud or lack of jurisdiction, he cannot attack the judgment collaterally. Quarles v. Miller, 86 F.3d 55 (4th Cir. 1996).

Where plaintiff sought to hold jointly and severally liable for breach of contract certain officers and directors of a foreign corporation which transacted business in this State without a certificate of authority, the absence of an allegation in the complaint or pleadings that any of the defendants ever resided in this State or actually came into the State to transact business required that the suit be dismissed for failure to state a cause of action upon which relief could be granted. Miller & Rhoads v. West, 442 F. Supp. 341 (E.D. Va. 1977).

Officers and directors of a foreign corporation which transacted business in this State without a certificate of authority were beyond the reach of the long-arm statute where plaintiff sought under this section to hold them jointly and severally liable for breach of contract, as the plaintiff neither alleged nor provided evidence that the corporation was an agent of the defendants either by express, incidental or apparent power. Miller & Rhoads v. West, 442 F. Supp. 341 (E.D. Va. 1977).

Applied in Verosol B.V. v. Hunter Douglas, Inc., 806 F. Supp. 582 (E.D. Va. 1992).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Violation of statute not in itself basis for piercing the corporate veil. - While subsection D of § 13.1-758 does specify the consequences of transacting business without authority, it does not include among those consequences the imposition of individual civil liability to the individuals who conduct the foreign corporation's affairs. SettlementRoom L.C. v. Certified Env'ts, Inc., 67 Va. Cir. 69, 2005 Va. Cir. LEXIS 31 (Fairfax County 2005).

Obtaining a certificate of authority not a condition precedent to filing a lawsuit. - Compliance with this section was not a condition precedent to the right to file a lawsuit, and a limited liability company's contract with the foundation was valid, as it was signed by one of the proposed principals and incorporators 12 days prior to the LLC obtaining its corporate status in Virginia. Geographic Network Affiliates-Int'l, Inc. v. Enter. for Empowerment Found., 68 Va. Cir. 185, 2005 Va. Cir. LEXIS 237 (Norfolk 2005).

Service on registered agent with revoked/inactive status. - It was proper to find a corporation in default because by serving the corporation's registered agent, parents met their burden, and the corporation failed to answer; the circuit court did not have a due process duty to ensure service of process on the corporation beyond statutory service on the registered agent listed by the Virginia State Corporation Commission for it, regardless of its revoked/inactive status. Tarek El Bourini v. Home Health Connection, Inc., 104 Va. Cir. 85, 2020 Va. Cir. LEXIS 2 (Fairfax County Jan. 3, 2020).

§ 13.1-759. Application for certificate of authority.

  1. To obtain a certificate of authority to transact business in the Commonwealth, a foreign corporation shall deliver an application to the Commission. The application shall be made on a form prescribed and furnished by the Commission. The application shall be signed in the name of the foreign corporation and set forth:
    1. The name of the foreign corporation, and if the foreign corporation is prevented by § 13.1-762 from using its name in the Commonwealth, a designated name that satisfies the requirements of subsection B of § 13.1-762;
    2. The foreign corporation's jurisdiction of formation, and if the foreign corporation was previously authorized or registered to transact business in the Commonwealth as a foreign corporation, limited liability company, business trust, limited partnership, or registered limited liability partnership, with respect to every such prior authorization or registration, (i) the name of the entity; (ii) the entity type; (iii) the state or other jurisdiction of incorporation, organization, or formation; and (iv) the entity identification number issued to it by the Commission;
    3. The foreign corporation's original date of incorporation, organization, or formation as an entity and its period of duration;
    4. The street address of the foreign corporation's principal office;
    5. The address of the proposed registered office of the foreign corporation in the Commonwealth (including both (i) the post office address with street and number, if any, and (ii) the name of the county or city in which it is located) and the name of its proposed registered agent in the Commonwealth at such address and that the registered agent is either (a) an individual who is a resident of Virginia and either an officer or director of the corporation or a member of the Virginia State Bar or (b) a domestic or foreign stock or nonstock corporation, limited liability company, or registered limited liability partnership authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth, the business office of which is identical with the registered office;
    6. The names and business addresses of the foreign corporation's directors and principal officers; and
    7. The number of shares the foreign corporation is authorized to issue, itemized by class.
  2. The foreign corporation shall deliver with the completed application a copy of its articles of incorporation and all amendments and corrections thereto duly authenticated by the Secretary of State or other official having custody of corporate records in its jurisdiction of formation.
  3. A foreign corporation is not precluded from receiving a certificate of authority to transact business in the Commonwealth because of any difference between the law of the foreign corporation's jurisdiction of formation and the law of the Commonwealth.
  4. If the Commission finds that the application complies with the requirements of law and that all required fees have been paid, it shall issue a certificate of authority to transact business in the Commonwealth.

(Code 1950, §§ 13.1-106, 13.1-107; 1956, c. 428; 1958, c. 564; 1975, c. 500; 1985, c. 522; 1994, c. 348; 2001, cc. 517, 541; 2002, c. 497; 2004, c. 274; 2015, c. 623; 2019, c. 734; 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 487.)

Editor's note. - Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 487, cl. 4 provides: "That the provisions of this act (i) shall be applied prospectively only; (ii) shall not affect the validity of any filing made, or other action taken, prior to July 1, 2021, with respect to the name of a stock corporation, nonstock corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or limited partnership; and (iii) shall not be construed to require any such stock corporation, nonstock corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or limited partnership that was in compliance with applicable laws regarding the distinguishability of its name prior to July 1, 2021, to change its name or take other action to comply with the requirements of this act."

The 2001 amendments. - The 2001 amendments by cc. 517 and 541 are identical, and in subdivision A 5, substituted "agent is either (a) an individual who is a resident of Virginia and either an officer" for "agent is (a) a resident of Virginia and an officer" and substituted "a domestic or foreign stock or nonstock corporation limited liability company, or registered limited liability partnership authorized to transact business in this Commonwealth" for "a professional corporation or professional, limited liability company registered under the provisions of § 54.1-3902."

The 2002 amendments. - The 2002 amendment by c. 497 inserted "and if the corporation is prevented by § 13.1-762 from using its own name in this Commonwealth, a designated name that satisfies the requirements of subsection B of § 13.1-762" at the end of subdivision A 1.

The 2004 amendments. - The 2004 amendment by c. 274 substituted "other jurisdiction" for "country" and added the language beginning "and if the corporation was previously authorized" at the end in subdivision A 2; substituted "other jurisdiction" for "country" in subsection B; and made minor stylistic changes.

The 2015 amendments. - The 2015 amendment by c. 623 deleted "own" preceding "name in the Commonwealth" in subdivision A 1; inserted "principal" in subdivision A 6; and deleted "classes and series, if any, within a" preceding "class" in subdivision A 7.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote subsection A, which read: "A foreign corporation may apply to the Commission for a certificate of authority to transact business in the Commonwealth. The application shall be made on forms prescribed and furnished by the Commission. The application shall set forth"; in subdivision A 1, inserted "foreign" preceding "corporation" twice; in subdivision A 2, substituted "The foreign corporation's jurisdiction of formation, and if the foreign corporation" for "The name of the state or other jurisdiction under whose law it is incorporated, and if the corporation"; in subdivision A 3, added "of the foreign corporation" at the end; rewrote subdivision A 6, which read: "The names and usual business addresses of the current directors and principal officers of the foreign corporation; and; in subdivision A 7, inserted "foreign" following "shares the"; in subsection B, substituted "in its jurisdiction of formation" for "the state or other jurisdiction under whose law it is incorporated"; added subsection C; and redesignated former subsection C as D.

The 2021 Sp. Sess. I amendments. - The 2021 amendment by Sp. Sess. I, c. 487, effective July 1, 2021, rewrote subdivision A 3, which read: "The date of incorporation and period of duration of the foreign corporation; and inserted "and corrections" in subsection B. For applicability clause, see Editor's note.

Law review. - For article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 35 U. Rich. L. Rev. 499 (2001).

For article reviewing changes in Virginia corporate and business law from June 2001 through May 2002, see 37 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1 (2002).

For 2007 annual survey article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 42 U. Rich. L. Rev. 273 (2007).

CASE NOTES

Reincorporation necessary to act as public service corporation. - To conduct business in Virginia, a foreign corporation must merely register with the State Corporation Commission. However, a foreign corporation must reincorporate in Virginia in order to act as a public service company. Johnson v. Colonial Pipeline Co., 830 F. Supp. 309 (E.D. Va. 1993).

Diversity jurisdiction lacking in action against pipeline company. - Even though pipeline company defendant was incorporated in Virginia, and its Virginia incorporation was an involuntary addition to its incorporation in Delaware, both plaintiffs and the defendant were citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia, and thus diversity jurisdiction was lacking under § 56-49 which requires a foreign corporation must reincorporate in Virginia in order to act as a public service corporation. Johnson v. Colonial Pipeline Co., 830 F. Supp. 309 (E.D. Va. 1993).

§ 13.1-760. Amended certificate of authority.

  1. A foreign corporation authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth shall obtain an amended certificate of authority from the Commission if it:
    1. Changes its corporate name in the jurisdiction of its formation;
    2. Changes its jurisdiction of formation; or
    3. Abandons or changes the designated name adopted by the foreign corporation for use in the Commonwealth pursuant to subsection B of § 13.1-762.
  2. The requirements of § 13.1-759 for obtaining an original certificate of authority apply to obtaining an amended certificate under this section.
  3. Whenever the articles of incorporation of a foreign corporation that is authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth are amended, within 30 days after the amendment becomes effective, the foreign corporation shall file with the Commission a copy of such amendment duly authenticated by the Secretary of State or other official having custody of corporate records in its jurisdiction of formation.

(Code 1950, §§ 13.1-112, 13.1-113; 1956, c. 428; 1976, c. 159; 1985, c. 522; 1986, c. 571; 1987, c. 431; 2015, c. 623; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2015 amendments. - The 2015 amendment by c. 623, in subsection A, added the subdivision designations, substituted "other jurisdiction" for "country" in subdivision A 1 and added subdivision A 2; in subsection C, substituted "transact business in the Commonwealth" for "do business in Virginia" and substituted "other jurisdiction" for "country"; and made stylistic changes.

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection A, added "if it" at the end; rewrote subdivision A 1, which read: "If it changes its corporate name or the state or other jurisdiction of its incorporation; or"; added subdivision A 2; redesignated former subdivision A 2 as 3; in subdivision A 3, inserted "foreign" preceding "corporation"; in subsection C, substituted "its jurisdiction of formation" for "the state or other jurisdiction under whose law it is incorporated"; and made stylistic changes.

§ 13.1-761. Effect of certificate of authority.

  1. A certificate of authority authorizes the foreign corporation to transact business in the Commonwealth subject, however, to the right of the Commonwealth to revoke the certificate as provided in this chapter.
  2. A foreign corporation holding a valid certificate of authority shall have no greater rights and privileges than a domestic corporation. The certificate of authority shall not be deemed to authorize the foreign corporation to exercise any of its corporate powers or purposes that a foreign corporation is forbidden by law to exercise in the Commonwealth.
  3. This chapter does not authorize the Commonwealth to regulate the organization or internal affairs of a foreign corporation authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth.

(Code 1950, §§ 13.1-102, 13.1-103, 13.1-108; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 2019, c. 734; 2020, c. 1226.)

Editor's note. - Acts 2020, c. 1226, cl. 3 provides: "That the provisions of the first and second enactments of this act shall become effective July 1, 2021."

The 2020 amendments. - The 2020 amendment by c. 1226, effective July 1, 2021, deleted "to which it is issued" following "corporation" in subsection A.

§ 13.1-762. Corporate name of foreign corporation.

  1. No certificate of authority shall be issued to a foreign corporation unless the corporate name of such foreign corporation satisfies the requirements of § 13.1-630.
  2. If the corporate name of a foreign corporation does not satisfy the requirements of § 13.1-630, to obtain or maintain a certificate of authority to transact business in the Commonwealth:
    1. The foreign corporation may use a designated name that adds the word "corporation," "incorporated," "company," or "limited," or the abbreviation "corp.," "inc.," "co.," or "ltd.," to its corporate name or, if it is a professional corporation, the words "professional corporation" or "a professional corporation" or the initials "P.C." or "PC" at the end of its corporate name, if it informs the Commission of the designated name; or
    2. If its real name is unavailable, the foreign corporation may use a designated name that is available, and that satisfies the requirements of § 13.1-630, if it informs the Commission of the designated name.

(Code 1950, §§ 13.1-104, 13.1-105, 13.1-114; 1956, c. 428; 1958, c. 564; 1975, c. 500; 1985, c. 522; 1986, cc. 232, 571; 2003, c. 592; 2005, cc. 379, 765; 2012, c. 63; 2015, c. 623.)

Editor's note. - Acts 2003, c. 592, cl. 3, provides: "That the provisions of this act (i) shall be applied prospectively only, (ii) shall not affect the validity of any filing made, or other action taken, prior to the effective date of this act [October 1, 2004] with respect to the name of a corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or limited partnership, and (iii) shall not be construed to require any such corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or limited partnership that was in compliance with applicable laws regarding the distinguishability of its name prior to the effective date of this act to change its name or take other action to comply with the requirements of this act."

Acts 2012, c. 63, cl. 2, provides: "That the provisions of this act (i) shall be applied prospectively only; (ii) shall not affect the validity of any filing made, or other action taken, prior to the effective date of this act with respect to the name of a corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or limited partnership; and (iii) shall not be construed to require any such corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or limited partnership that was in compliance with applicable laws regarding the propriety of its name prior to the effective date of this act to change its name or take other action to comply with the requirements of this act."

The 2003 amendments. - The 2003 amendment by c. 592, effective October 1, 2004, in subdivision A 3, rewrote paragraphs a, c and d and added paragraphs e to l; and added subsection E.

The 2005 amendments. - The 2005 amendment by c. 379, effective March 21, 2005, in subsection E, added "designation," substituted " § 13.1-544.1, subsection A of § 13.1-630, subsection A of § 13.1-1012, § 13.1-1104, subdivision 1 of § 50-73.2, and subdivision A 2 of § 50-73.78" for "this chapter, Chapter 7 ( § 13.1-542 et seq.), 10 ( § 13.1-801 et seq.), 13 ( § 13.1-1100 et seq.), and 14 ( § 13.1-1200 et seq.) of this title, and Chapter 2.1 ( § 50-73.1 et seq.) of Title 50," and made minor stylistic changes.

The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted "the Commonwealth" for "this Commonwealth" throughout; deleted "of this section" following "subsection C" in subdivision A 3; deleted "of this section" following "subsection A" in subsection B; and made minor stylistic changes.

The 2012 amendments. - The 2012 amendment by c. 63 rewrote the section.

The 2015 amendments. - The 2015 amendment by c. 623 in subdivision B 1, substituted "use a designated name that adds" for "add" and "or, if it is a professional corporation, the words "professional corporation" or "a professional corporation" or the initials "P.C." or "PC" at the end of its corporate name, if it informs the Commission of the designated name" for "for use in the Commonwealth."

§ 13.1-763. Registered office and registered agent of foreign corporation.

  1. Each foreign corporation authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth shall continuously maintain in the Commonwealth:
    1. A registered office, which may be the same as any of its places of business; and
    2. A registered agent, who shall be:
      1. An individual who is a resident of Virginia and either an officer or director of the corporation or a member of the Virginia State Bar, and whose business office is identical with the registered office; or
      2. A domestic or foreign stock or nonstock corporation, limited liability company or registered limited liability partnership authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth, the business office of which is identical with the registered office; provided such a registered agent (i) shall not be its own registered agent and (ii) shall designate by instrument in writing, acknowledged before a notary public, one or more natural persons at the office of the registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand may be served and shall continuously maintain at least one such person at that office. Whenever any such person accepts service, a photographic copy of such instrument shall be attached to the return.
  2. The sole duty of the registered agent is to forward to the foreign corporation at its last known address any process, notice, or demand that is served on the registered agent.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-109; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 1994, c. 348; 2000, c. 162; 2001, cc. 517, 541; 2019, c. 734.)

The 2000 amendments. - The 2000 amendment by c. 162, in subdivision A 2 b, deleted "or" following "professional corporation," inserted "or registered limited liability partnership" preceding "registered" and inserted "with the Virginia State Bar" thereafter.

The 2001 amendments. - The 2001 amendments by cc. 517 and 541, are identical, and in the introductory language of subdivision A 2, substituted "who shall be" for "which agent shall be"; in subdivision A 2 a, inserted "An individual who is," substituted "and either an officer" for "who is an officer," and substituted "business office" for "business address"; in subdivision A 2 b, substituted "A domestic foreign stock or nonstock corporation, limited liability company" for "A professional corporation, professional limited liability company," substituted "authorized to transact business in this Commonwealth" for "registered with the Virginia State Bar under the provisions of § 54.1-3902" and added the language beginning "provided such a registered agent ..."; and in subsection B, substituted "any process, notice or demand" for "any notice."

The 2019 amendments. - The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection B, inserted "foreign" preceding "corporation"; and made stylistic changes.

Law review. - For article, "Corporate and Business Law," see 35 U. Rich. L. Rev. 499 (2001).

OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

"Principal office." - For purposes of subdivision (2) of § 55-58.1, "principal office" may be defined according to the definition of this term provided in Title 13.1. A corporation's registered office does not satisfy the requirements of subdivision (2) of § 55-58.1 unless such office also meets the definition of "principal office." See opinion of Attorney General to The Honorable J. Chapman Petersen, Member, Senate of Virginia, 11-053, 2012 Va. AG LEXIS 34 (9/14/2012).

§ 13.1-764. Change of registered office or registered agent of a foreign corporation.

  1. A foreign corporation authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth may change its registered office or registered agent, or both, upon filing with the Commission a statement of change on a form prescribed and furnished by the Commission that sets forth:
    1. The name of the foreign corporation;
    2. The address of its current registered office;
    3. If the current registered office is to be changed, the post office address, including the street and number, if any, of the new registered office, and the name of the city or county in which it is to be located;
    4. The name of its current registered agent;
    5. If the current registered agent is to be changed, the name of the new registered agent; and
    6. That after the change or changes are made, the corporation will be in compliance with the requirements of § 13.1-763.
  2. A statement of change shall be filed with the Commission by a foreign corporation if its registered agent dies, resigns, or ceases to satisfy the requirements of § 13.1-763.
  3. A foreign corporation's registered agent may sign a statement as required above if (i) the business address of the registered agent changes to another post office address within the Commonwealth, (ii) the name of the county or city in which the registered office is located changes or is incorrect on the Commission's records, or (iii) the name of the registered agent has been legally changed. A foreign corporation's new registered agent may sign and submit for filing a statement as required above if (a) the former registered agent is a business entity that has been merged into the new registered agent, (b) the instrument of merger is on record with the Commission, and (c) the new registered agent is an entity that is qualified to serve as a registered agent pursuant to § 13.1-763. In either instance, the registered agent or surviving entity shall forthwith file a statement as required above, which shall recite that a copy of the statement shall be mailed to the principal office of the foreign corporation on or before the business day following the day on which the statement is filed with the Commission.

(Code 1950, § 13.1-110; 1956, c. 428; 1958, c. 564; 1975, c. 500; 1985, c. 522; 1986, c. 622; 2003, c. 597; 2010, c. 434; 2019, c. 734; 2020, c. 1226.)

Editor's note. - Acts 2020, c. 1226, cl. 3 provides: "That the provisions of the first and second enactments of this act shall become effective July 1, 2021."

The 2020 amendments. - The 2020 amendment by c. 1226, effective July 1, 2021, in the first sentence of subsection C, inserted clause (ii) and redesignated former clause (ii) as clause (iii), and made a stylistic change.

§ 13.1-765. Resignation of registered agent of foreign corporation.

  1. A registered agent may resign as agent for the foreign corporation by signing and filing with the Commission a statement of resignation stating (i) the name of the foreign corporation, (ii) the name of the agent, and (iii) that the agent resigns from serving as registered agent for the foreign corporation. The statement of resignation shall be accompanied by a certification that the registered agent will have a copy of the statement mailed to the principal office of the foreign corporation by certified mail on or before the business day following the day on which the statement is filed. When the statement of resignation takes effect, the registered office is also discontinued.
  2. A statement of resignation takes effect on the earlier of (i) 12:01 a.m. on the thirty-first day after the date on which the statement was filed with the Commission or (ii) the date on which a statement of change to appoint a registered agent is filed, in accordance with § 13.1-764, with the Commission.

(1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2010, c. 434; 2019, c. 734; 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 487.)

Cross references. - For the effect failing to file a statement of change, following a resignation under this section, can have on the corporation's certificate of authority, see § 13.1-768.

Editor's note. - Acts 2021, Sp. Sess.
